If you have one day to spend it , you should do this tour. It costs US$ 175,00/pax, but you have breakfast and lunch included as well one tour guide in Fort. The boat is one fast cat but it's not very confortable.

This is a wonderful national park. It has so much history and has various entrances. It's a $25 entrance per vehicle. It can be used over 7 days. Save your receipt. Plan your tour with ample time to park and visit the visitor centers to view the exhibits, watch the videos, listen to the ranger talks, take a tram tour and walk around the trails. Our fav was the Anigha trail. Dress accordingly it could rain be very hot and can be very buggy!

We went with our toddler (22 months), teens, teenage son, and grandma. Everyone enjoyed this park. The weather was perfect - 70 and windy with sun- so no mosquitos. We stopped by the visitor center near homestead to start and then went to Anhina Trail. We saw 4 alligators. We skipped the limbo gumbo trail which is right next to Anhina, but I wish we would've done this jungle-like trail. We then drove an easy 50 minutes to Flamingo with a small stop to see the overlook. Once at flamingo, we are at the restaurant, which was surprisingly good. Alligator nuggets were delicious. Bring your own water bottles if you have them because they charge $2.50 for a bottle of water. We saw manatees in the marina by chance. When asked, our waitress suggested we make it to Mahogany trail to try to find the nesting owl before sunset. This was on our way back to the homestead entrance. It was amazing at sunset. It felt like we were in the jungle. Very cool experience. My favorite part of the trip, maybe because it was so unexpected and at sunset. This was an almost-all day park. I wish we would've started earlier so we could've done all the trails on the way this flamingo.

Even if you are short on time, don't miss the Ernest Coe Visitor Center and Anhinga Trail. The Visitor Center is informative and a great primer for the trail. The Anhinga Trail is perfect for anyone wanting a taste of the Everglades. We saw wheelchairs, strollers, the very young and old, and every nationality. We also saw five alligators, various species of South Florida bird, and the beautiful landscape of the Everglades. For $25 per car, you have 7 days of access to the Park.

Took half the day and spent $20 to go into the Everglades National Park. We were warned to have bug spray at the gate but we entered the park even though we didn't have any. Bad idea!! You can't get out of the car unless you want vampire mosquitoes to eat you alive. I was with 2 teenagers. They were not interested in taking hikes especially with the risk of an unsolicited blood drive for bugs. Haha It was our own fault we didn't have more fun. I suggest you buy bug spray before entering the park. We did not ride the boats so cannot comment. The park seemed nice otherwise. It is well maintained.

We entered the park through Flamingo side...we drove for 30 minutes and saw nothing until we got to Flamingo where there was a building with a few stuffed creatures inside. We were attacked by mosquitos, there was no one there to greet us, or lead us to places of interedt. Very nothingness. I'm not sure why we paid $20 to get into the park. We left as soon as we figured out there was nothing of interest there. We saw no wildlife, only stuffed creatures.

Make sure to spend at least 3 days exploring this national park. Start off at the visitor's center just outside the entrance. Check out the introductory film and talk to the friendly volunteers to orientate you to the activities you want to do. The entry fee is only $10 for your car - and this is good for a full week! Take advantage of the free ranger-guided tours whenever possible. You will be amazed at the birds, alligators and other wildlife throughout the park. Winter is the best time for wildlife, comfortable temperatures and lack of bugs.

Called in yesterday and paid $10 dollars for two of us to enter this park. We had initially wanted to take an airboat trip over the glades but when we realised how noisy they are, it was obvious that we wouldn't get the chance to see much in the way of wildlife!!

Visited Fire Island during visit to family home in Islip, New York. Cost us about $80 round trip,to ferry across bay. Nice ferry ride. Once there, it is rather unique with many restaurants and eateries. Very expensive though. Charming little houses with walkways to opposite side of island and beaches. Roving police officer on beach handing out $100 plus tickets to anyone drinking anything besides water. Not welcoming at all. Water is cold and murky. Could be I am used to Florida with warm clear water and free access to most beaches. Wouldn't recommend due to high cost and lack of hospitality.

It was really neat to see giant fossilized redwood stuns in the middle of Colorado. You can see most of the sights via a short trail. We spent about an hour and a half walking different trails with two young children. Worth the trip and $5 a person.

Yup I didn't know either. Seriously I probably wouldn't drive hours out of the way to get here, but if your close it is certainly worth the time. Admission is inexpensive, the rangers are all very nice and knowledgeable. We were the only ones there for a presentation so the ranger really catered to us. Check out the junior ranger program!!!! It's such a neat way for the kids to learn.

We just found ourselves in the right time at the right place. Enjoyed the raising of the flag. Costumed interpreters explained about the 15 star flag and what the Lewis and Clark expedition went thru while wintering at the fort.

A visit to this site of Lewis and Clark's Oregon winter quarters takes you back more than 200 years. You'll sense the challenges the expedition team met. A replica of the fort they built to shelter them from wind and rain during their 4-month sojourn makes real the hard beds and dark rooms they endured. Children will love trying out quill pens and seeing animal skins and a long rifle up close, thanks to the friendly park guides. The museum and a half-hour movie provide details and stories, with especially informative descriptions of how much the native peoples aided the U.S. explorers. HELPFUL HINT: If you're "of a certain age," get your lifetime national park pass this August for $10, before the price goes up!

My family visited Fort Clatsop last summer and thought it was very interesting and informative! All of the workers were very knowledgeable and helpful. There are also several hikes that you can take nearby if the weather is nice. We bought an Oregon Coast 5 Day Pass, so it covered entry, vehicle parking and day use fees at all Oregon State and Federal fee sites along the Oregon Coast. It's a great deal if you are spending a few days on the coast!

Lewis&Clark lovers, rejoice! Feel the spirit of exploration as you tour their recreated dorms and hike the easy trail through lush forest and wooden bridges. Attend short lectures and demonstrations, and get your fill of the westward movement! Happy travels!

At only $3.00 per adult it was well worth it. The grounds are dog friendly. You can walk your dogs throughout the property. Easy walk if you're out of shape or have seniors with you. Very interesting and historical.

My family has visited a lot of historical places during our travels and this one did not disappoint. A model of what Lewis and Clark built was rebuilt for visitors to experience. There were many workers dressed in period clothes hanging around to answer questions and periodically they would have formal talks and demonstrations. There is a small fee, $5 per adult, children 16 and younger free. Very reasonable and worth the experience.

The effort to maintain and refurbish one of the most historic points along the Oregon Trail is well worth the time and effort of making a visit. It makes the life of the mid-19th century American cavalry real. The 49th Mounted Rifles (today's descendant units are part of the 3rf Infantry Division) patrolled out of Ft. Laramie protecting wagon trains from modern day Julesburg, CO to South Pass, WY.
It was such a great to spend a couple of hours. It’s 10$ to get in with discounts for over 62 and military discounts. I could have stayed there all day. Great place to see

To walk among these walls and walk on top of the fort brings history alive. The Park Rangers give excellent talks. If you are a "Senior citizen", be sure to ask about the lifetime park pass for life. It is only $10 and gets you into all parks in Florida.

We had a great time on the tour of this amazing Spanish fort, completed in 1742. We arrived at around 1015, and the tour left at 1030 AM. A boat ride is necessary to reach the fort, and the best part is that everything is free. Tickets are limited by the number of spots on the boats. There were two boats when I went. Once you arrive, the guide gives you a great oral history of the fort, then lets you explore it yourself for about 20 minutes. One of the most interesting parts of your exploration of the fort will be if you are able to climb the ladder through the small space to reach the top of the fort. Not everyone will be able to do this for a variety of reasons. I would recommend this site to anyone who is looking for a fun, historic and budget-friendly good time and is interested in Florida's Spanish origins.

So much history and the Fort was a fantastic experience. My wife and I have a National Park Pass which made entrance very easy and inexpensive. While we knew some of the history from the local area - going through the various rooms and lectures at the Fort brought the history home. A fantastic day of learning.....

South of St. Augustine on A1A you will find the park on your right side. It's very well maintained and managed. A ferry runs visitors to and from the Fort. Tickets for the ferry are available at no cost in the main building and is first come, first serve. The entire park is beautiful and well worth the time and effort to get there. The rest rooms are clean and convenient, there are picnic tables under the oaks. Snack machines are in the area. The Fort is entertaining for all generations.

I asked why this was a national monument and the reply was that it is the a surviving example of a Spanish watchtower. The short ferry ride was nice, and the ranger we had on site basically gave a blurb and then waited for questions. I kept wondering what the operating budget was and comparing it to the value of the visit. Admission is free.

Another fine example of the Spanish military presence in the early days of Florida. When it was in use, seven people would man this site for thirty days and that must have been a lonely, miserable time. Admission to the site is by the only free boat ride in the area and it is a national park. The ranger guides are excellent. It is a short drive down highway one and worth the trip.

I haven't been to Fort McHenry since elementary school and my husband and I decided to go and relearn the history. There was a ton of information from the video to speaking with park rangers and signage detailing history. The location is beautiful with views of the water and we're so lucky to have this piece of history in my own backyard, so to speak. At 10 a.m. each day they raise the flag, which we didn't know ahead of time and participated in the tradition. It was amazing! The ranger gave the history surrounding why they use a 15 start and stripped flag along with the song they played which is not the Star Spangled Banner. We spent more time than we expected because there is a lot to see and learn. Minimal fee of $10 per person for adult which gives you access to the fort and you can stroll around the outskirts along the water.

This attraction recently underwent a multi-year, multi-million dollar facelift and the results are no less than spectacular... Each year on July 4 we purchase a replica of the original flag that was Frances Scott Key's inspiration for the National Anthem... The Park Rangers arrange to have our flags hoisted and provide a certification that they flew over the site on our Nation's Birthday... A special gift for our many friends who have visited and been mightily impressed with Fort McHenry..

We took our girls (14 and 11) to Ft McHenry. They were not excited about going at first but once we got there and they could run through the underground bunkers, see the large cannons and cannonballs and stroll into the houses they changed their minds. There is a $10 fee for adults and children under 12 that you purchase at the welcome center before you are allowed in the Fort. We took the water taxi from the Inner Harbor to get to the Fort but took an Uber to LP Steamers (5 min ride) to lunch after we were finished.

Great patriotic site. Well presented and preserved. Plenty of parking and a safe environment. Cannon loading and firing with explanations. It's a national park so entry is $10, but wait..... if you are 62 or over, a lifetime senior pass is $10 and good at all national parks and gets a whole car load in on the one pass. Fair amount of walking if you want to see everything.
This is a place to see if visiting Baltimore however be aware it is $10 per person to go inside the fort of this US Parks location.

Went to the Fort to get my National Parks Senior Pass. Stayed for the visual presentation about the flag. Very enjoyable. Short enough to keep children interested. Very nice gift shop. No food on grounds, but lots of spaces to picnic.

We visited for the third time and it was just as good as the first. It is easier driving as the water taxi can take quite a bit longer. It was hot but they did a demonstration with the large flag outside. The movie and museum is great especially when at the end of the movie the screen goes down to show the fort and flag in a large picture window. It is a bit more pricey than other National Park monuments as it is $10 per person, which can be expensive for families, to go into the fort. Other parks have just charged a flat $10 or less fee per car. The visitor center and grounds are free however.

Excellent site full of history and laid out very well. Be sure to see the video in the Visitors Center. There's a charge only if you want to go into the fort. Otherwise, roaming around the extensive grounds is free. If you have a National Parks pass, be sure to take it. That allowed 2 other adults, 3 kids under the age of 16, and me to all get in for $10. Views are incredible. Our time there was very interesting and worth the effort to get there. Parking is ample and free

I visited this park on a nice day. It is a little windy being next to the water. The line was fast and only cost $10 to see everything. The 10 minute movie was a good start and the artifacts are very interesting. The Fort is well preserved and really made you understand how it functioned. There were alot of school age kids there during my visit, but it was never too crowded. The views were beautiful. A bit of walking, but I expected that. You can walk all around the grounds, but you have to pay to see the fort itself. I enjoyed my visit.
We enjoyed the fort and its history. $10 per person is a bit high, but we love history, and the place is an important part of this country's legacy.
location: Finger Lakes Wine Country, New York

text: For my McHenry is an awesome place to get pictures. There is plenty of parking for anytime of day. When you first walk in, they will have you pay ten dollars( 16 years of age and older). Anyone younger than 16 goes in for free. You watch a short film about the battle. After they play the national anthem (they raise the screen to look at the flag). After it's a tour! They talk about why the fort looks like a star. It's hard for me to explain like the pros( the tour guides). You can take epic pictures anywhere in the fort, like in the taverns. The guides told us "If you want to build a fort a tavern is the start". I highly suggest coming here for a smack in the face by history. It's really awesome! Happy traveling!
Was honestly not 100% sold on visiting from the pictures on TripAdvisor and the $10 price, however after taking my time to visit I can easily say it was worth it.
Worth it. You only have to pay the 10 dollars to enter the fort itself and it's good for 7 days, if you come back and just want to walk outside in the perimeter you don't have to spend a penny.

The gift shop at the Fort has some spyglasses that are said to have been used in the past centuries - about $80 per unit. You could also buy an antique sword for around two or three thousand dollars. There are much less expensive offerings as well. Just be careful of the cute little picture books; some are not very historically accurate. I highly recommend watching the short movie before touring the fort to set the stage for what you are about to consider. Friendly park rangers are on-hand to answer questions as you self-tour the fort. I recommend following Google Maps driving directions to get there, it saves time.

Be sure to get your National Parks Passport stamped. This place was truly magical with all of its historical films, displays and grounds. We were lucky enough to be there in the afternoon when they had flag change with guest participation.

We took our children here for a visit. They are 10 year old twins and a 4 year old. They all enjoyed walking around and exploring the grounds. It was free parking which was a big plus after spending $100 in Baltimore for 3 days. The views are beautiful. All of the park rangers were extremely knowledgable and answered every question we had.
Full of history a must go place during your visit to Baltimore, very accessible, clean, nice views, worth the money you pay wich is only $10adults kids under 16 are free.

We had a great time at this often overlooked historic sight. Admission is free for kids under 16 and only 10 dollars for everyone else. Make sure to see the 10 minute movie in the visitor center to start your visit. Inside the fort are various exhibits many with additional short videos. Make sure to watch them too. The view is awesome from the fort and it gives you a great idea of how the battle back in 1814 unfolded. It takes no more than 90 minutes total to tour the fort. Parking is ample and the folks working are there are helpful, although watch out for the Rangers who will tell you to stay on the paths at all times.

This is a national park and historic landmark so it is an amazing place to take out-of-town visitors or go if you were a local. The park rangers are very knowledgeable and give impromptu insights and tours. Very reasonable (less than $10) for a quality experience.

Visited during the 200th anniversary of the writing of the Star Spangled Banner. Learned so much about the War of 1812 and the writing of our national anthem, a subject brushed over in history class. The fort was an impressive design, the history of it's many uses was intriguing, the story of the battle over Baltimore was interesting. The visitor center film describes the story quite well for those who do not want to pay $7 to visit the fort. But it is well woth the price of admission to walk the grounds and experience the life of the military in 1814. A great historical experience,

There are two sites here. Free parking. The visitor's center is ironically the free part. Going onto the actual grounds of the fort cost less than a movie ($7, free for kids). Start at the visitor's center, get the background, watch the movie, and then (spoiler) the wall opens up and you'll see the fort in the distance.

I took my 8 year old here over President's day week. Admission was free and guides were very helpful. The visitor's center has a nice collection of background information although he didn't stop to read all of it. Even though it was cold, it was a very sunny day and we walked the grounds exploring all the shoveled paths. Because of the exhibits in the visitor's center he had a good idea of what he was looking at when we went out to the fort. I didn't know that the fort was well used during other eras and we especially liked looking at the exhibit in the fort that shows what they dug up where and from what time period it was from. All in all we spent about and hour and a half, which might not be enough for a history teacher but for her son it was perfect. Would recommend this during the off season as I can imagine it gets very crowded in the summer.

We'd been here before with our children. Decided to visit again since we'd heard that the visitor center had been updated for the bicentennial. We were glad we stopped. Nothing beats an infusion of patriotism on a Sunday morning! The update was very well done. The visitor center is free; I believe the tour of the fort is $7.

I'm so glad I was able to convince my friends to stop by on our way to New York. I won't spoil it, but the show in the museum is truly moving especially if you enjoy history. It's only seven dollars and totally worth your time.

Visiting Fort McHenry was like stepping back in time. They had a wonderful free presentation that really helped me understand the importance of the war of 1812 and Baltimore's role in that. It was worth the few dollars to go into the old fort and really get a feeling for the battle that gave us our national anthem.

My family and I love to travel to as many National Monuments, National Parks and National Historic Sites as we can and this one is one of my favorites. It's well preserved and the park does a wonderful job with its displays and Ranger led talks setting the scene for the famous siege which inspired the Star Spangled Banner. It is about a $20 cab right from the Inner Harbor. Getting back to the harbor is cheap and easy. There is a bus stop right outside the monument gate which will take you past the stadiums and back to the harbor.

Visiting Fort McHenry for the first time and think its incredible. $7 entrance fee to support the exhibit well worth it. This is a great tribute to the battle of Baltimore and the men who defended the city almost two hundred years ago

The Inner Harbor of Baltimore is a fantastic place to visit but don't overlook Fort McHenry, located at the tip of the Federal Hill part of town. The easiest way to get there is by water taxi. It only costs $8 for an all-day pass on the water taxi but if you plan on seeing things in the Harborplace area go for the $18 ticket which includes not only the water taxi day pass but also admission to all the ships (Constellation, Torsk, Chesapeak Lightship, etc.).

It was one of the stops along inner harbor's water taxi ride and it was worth the visit. The grounds are beautiful and seem to be well maintained. In the visitor's center, there are displays and exhibits about the Star Spangled Banner and the War of 1812. There is also an interesting short film about the battle that inspred Francis Scott Key to write the national anthem. The film and the exhibits in the visitor's center are all free. If you want to go inside the actual fort, it costs $7. If you go on the top, there is a marvelous 360 degree view. It was a nice history lesson.

What a great visit. Admission was free but I would've paid for sure. A lot of history, great staff. They have a section of the trail blocked off were you can get our of your car and look and see the actual wagon wheel ruts on the trail. It gave me gooses bumps. Then you drive a little further to actually get to the place. There are signs with arrows right on the trail showing the direction of it and a lot of old ruins, including the jail. Some geese were waiting for their eggs to hatch and they kept watch over us. The staff love their job there, and it shows. They have a movie to watch in the beginning if you like and a gift shop, water fountain and bathrooms. A definite stop if you are in the area. One note: It was windy when we were there so I would have a light jacket with a hood to protect your ears or some kind of hat.
Astounding display of nature. A must do. $20 admin per car worth it. It's about 45 min drive from Hilo, Big Island, Hawaii
park: Friends of Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park

text: The 30 minute movie is a must! Provides the history to appreciate George Clark's accomplishments. Such a beautiful National Park. We started our Passports here. Looking forward to filling the books up. The volunteers and staff are very courteous and helpful. Excellent trip! Thanks!
park: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park

text: Arrived at this site in the late morning. Note, we stayed overnight in Silver City, and it was a two hour very demanding drive through switchbacks and narrow roads to get to the place. So, be prepared to start early and like us, bring a lunch and plenty of water. There is nothing around the monument where you can get supplies or a meal. On arrival, we were met by a friendly Park employee who gave us a briefing on the site and what we needed to be aware of. Most particularly, there are bears and snakes in those woods, so be careful. Anyway, you are given a small map, which guides you through a trail set out in the woods and which winds upwards some 150 feet in elevation. It's not a tough climb, but stopping every once in a while and sipping from your water bottle - a good thing to bring with you - makes it a bit easier. Anyway, pretty soon you arrive at the caves where early inhabitants lived and you are greeted - if you are lucky to hit the right time - by anotyher Park employee who informs you about the dwellings, who lived there, how they survived, etc. It is truly amazing anyone lived in these caves, but given the alternatives, one can understand why they did. The area is beautiful, with several lovely opportunities for pictures. There are a couple of cave drawings as well - somewhat small and inconspicuous - but they are there. The climb down is equally enjoyable and winds you back to your starting point. Total time up and back about a two and a half hours. You could linger a bit more if you wanted to. There are also a couple of other trails that are available that show you some more drawings and a couple of other caves. We opted to not do those. The Visitor's Center is a few miles away and also worth a visit. Overall a very good place to see. The Park employees are as usual very friendly and helpful. Another example of our tax dollars being put to good use.

Definetly worth the trip!! The drive from Silver City is beautiful! The visitor's center provides great info. The place itself is a true natural wonder. It is only a little less than 2 miles as a hike, so anyone can go. You get to visit a few caverns, the entry fee is only 3$, plus there is a free guided tour for those who want. If you're in the area, a must see!!

This place is in the middle of nowhere. But worth the drive. It's were the first continent long railroads joined in 1869. There is a train demonstration, films, exhibits and a good selection of railroad books. The staff was friendly and helpful. Restroom was clean at 4:30pm. Cost is $7 unless you have the National Park annual pass.
We thoroughly enjoyed our tour which only cost about $150 which we thought was very good value.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: I made an error by reserving the wrong day when booking this trip. I didn't notice until I showed up and discovered I was booked for the next week. The staff was very accommodating and arranged for me to fly shortly thereafter. The operation was very smooth considering the number of helicopters operating out of their terminal. The pilot was very skilled and managed a smooth ride for my first time heli-flyer wife. This is the best possible way to see the Grand Canyon and worth every dollar.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: First ever flight in a helicopter and I could not believe the incredible experience!! Start the experience with the booking, the reception desk, (yes the weigh you and info is kept confidential), and the preflight safety video in the lounge. The take care of you, period. Helped you into the helicopter made sure the headphones and belts were correct. Lift off and away we went. Just a few minutes over the forest and a gentle swoop downward to the best view I have ever had. The flight was spectacular, the pilot was awesome, telling us a few tidbits as well as the required narrative. Even showed us a herd of buffalo in the distance. Cannot say enough good about this experience and the 40 or so dollars for the long ride was well worth it. If you are thinking about a helicopter tour of the Grand Canyon use this company!!! Well worth the little bit extra it costs.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: Wow such an amazing park. We enjoyed every second of it. 30$ park entrance unless you have a national parks pass which I recommend.

This is deffitenly something to cross off the bucket list. We arrived at the airport/helicopters and were greeted by friendly staff. We payed $140 for the 2 of us tjat included the famous sky walk and a pick up drop off shuttle bus that ran every 10 mins. I would tell everybody who hasnt been here to visit its simply, breathtaking.

I had not been to the canyon in over 20 years and after visiting, I can't believe I waited so long. The pass is $30 but good for a week and there's so much to see and do, you could definitely spend a few days here. It was just my son and I so I bought a single "walk-in" pass in nearby Tusayan for $15 (kids are free), took the FREE shuttle into the park which bypasses the main entrance and goes straight to the Visitor's Center. From there you can catch more free shuttles to different vistas and lodging. Definitely try to watch the sunset at Hopi Point (red shuttle). Shuttles will be packed but be patient and wait in line instead of trying to walk the Rim trail. It's longer than you think. Catching the shuttle back is like cramming into a Disneyland tram (with ridiculous lines to boot), so just be mentally prepared for long waits. It's worth the sunset view. When you get hot, Bright Angel Lodge serves ice cream at an outdoor shop. Some of the gift shops in the galleries and lodges have items that the Visitor Center gift shop doesn't have. Also, in summer, although it was only 85 degrees, you are at high altitude in thinner air. We walked a (very) short ways down Bright Angel Trail and people were overheating and dehydrated quickly. If you have active little ones, hold onto their hand because there are sheer drop offs with NO guard rails all along the Rim trail and other trails. We also saw elk that walked right up into the parking lots. Pictures cannot capture the depth and magnitude that hit your senses in this amazing place!

What a spectacular drive, they call it the million dollar highway and is awesome. If your in the area don't miss this drive. Stop at the Escalante Visitor Center watch the video and get maps of things to do so you can go back and hike some of the beautiful slot canyons and drive over Hell's Backbone. Take time to stop for photos and dine at the Burr Trail Grill of Hell's Backbone Grill in Boulder before heading back. On the drive back stop at the Escalante river and take a walk in the cool water.
Thee most beautiful drive on Highway 12 from Boulder, Utah to Bryce Canyon. The trailhead is at a campground with good signage, and a trail map. Be prepared to pay a $5 day use fee.

If you do nothing else while in southern Utah you have to drive the million dollar highway between Escalante and Boulder. I wouldn't want to do it in anything larger than a class C motor home. It can get a bit hairy if you are scared of heights but the view can't be beat. The road surface is real good and there was very little traffic. The views are amazing.

The tour leaves from Teton Village, which is important if you are staying near town square in Jackson, because its about a 10 minute drive to the meeting place to get on the jeep. Our tour guide Jacqueline was awesome. She knew everything about everything. The animals, the grass, the trees, the history, everything. She was very passionate. We saw moose, bison, elk, and some other animals. Its kind of like hunting, you need to keep your eyes peeled to spot the animals. They are really not that close. They give you binoculars. Its was a good trip though. Btw, there is a $15 charge per person to get into the park, which is not included. And the trip is a solid 4+ hours. Great value for the time, but its a long trip.

We landed at the Jackson Hole Airport,grabbed a rental car and headed north toward Yellowstone. We entered the Grand Teton Park at the Moran entrance and within minutes arrived at Oxbow Bend and were overwhelmed with the beauty of the Tetons. The park roads were in great shape and we were surprised how quickly we could get from one attraction to another. We simply followed the scenic route stopping whenever we wanted. We saw bison, eagles and a few deer. We also stopped at the Moose Entrance and went to the visitor center where we got to touch all sort of animal pelts, planned a future 3 day hike and watched a 20 minute film about the park. Afterward we headed south and passed the numerous old homesteads and were back to Jackson Hole in 5 hours. What a great day trip for kids and adults :car- $50 entrance fee -$30 nature -priceless!

This is an absolutely magical view. The glaciers are magnificent and awe inspiring. The driving is not for the faint of heart as the elevation is quite high and there are some wicked turns. There is a fee for the park, however if you are military it is free, and for those over 62 of age a $10.00 fee allows access to ALL US National Parks for a lifetime for you and all members in your vehicle

This was our last stop on a 12-day trip to Colorado. Thanks to other reviews, we knew that we could rent a sled or snow board at the restaurant/shop located just 3-4 miles outside of the entrance to the park. It was $20/day to rent a sled and we rented two for the five of us. It's a toss up if you want to rent one for each person. The cost adds up and you'd have to each carry a sled the whole time but you could bypass a few of the steep climbs required to hand it off to the next person. Park in the dunes lot so you don't have to walk the mile from the Visitor's Center to the trailhead. You will walk through water at the start of the trail so either wear water shoes or plan to take off your socks and shoes to walk through. Don't wear flip flops or sandals- the sand can be hot and it's a lot of climbing. The climbing was tough! We thought we would go to the High Dune but opted for a shorter climb since we were so out of breath. The kids (8, 11, 13) actually stopped and sat down while my husband and I (in our 40's) slowly made the climb to the top. We had the sleds with us and really enjoyed the ride down! Use your feet to help steer so you don't go sideways. If you are going fast and the sled turns, the sled will wedge into the sand and you will go flying. If you go down a steep hill, it's a TON of fun but... man, that walk back to the top is a killer! Bring water! We had two camelbak hydration backpacks and they were perfect. The only negative was that we didn't realize just how sandy we would be when we were done. We were literally covered from head to toe with sand and, since the van was packed and ready for our drive home, we didn't plan a change of clothes. There is a shower area out in the open by the bathrooms that helps get rid of some of the sand but, despite our best efforts, we were still finding sand in our socks, shoes, hair, and underwear the rest of the way home. All in all, it was a fantastic experience and we would highly recommend this to anyone in the area!
$15 per car. Worth every penny! Bring sunscreen, aqua socks, mosquito repellent, goggles and a tobaggon to sled the sand!

The Great Sand Dunes are very interesting. Not something you would expect near the snowy mountains of Colorado. I thought it was worth checking it out. Parking can be tricky and it costs $15 per car. There is a little creek you need to cross if you want to walk on the Dunes, so be prepared to get your shoes off and your feet wet. The hike on the Dunes was a good workout.

We rented sand sleds for $20 at the nearby Great Sand Dunes Oasis. It was quite a hike to the tops of the dunes, but we had fun trying to slide to the bottom without falling off the sled! It was a great experience! The creek was low but there were some children playing in the water. You should take insect repellent if you're staying near the water.

For people who want to visit Washington DC AND who love camping, consider camping at Greenbelt National Park, a very wooded campground that's 13 miles from the White House, and about a mile from the end of the DC metro's green line. Tent camping is $20/night ($10 for seniors), and RV and other forms of camping are also available. We plan to bring all three grandkids (5,6, and 8 years old now) up from NC for a week next June as soon as school is out, to see the Smithsonian Museums, monuments, etc.

So we went when the park first started their "reservation" process. Yes, you have to make a reservation. If you don't have one, they won't let you watch the sunrise. If I remember correctly, you have to pay $1.50 for a reservation. But even when you reserve an entrance, there's still a lot of people. There are two locations to watch the sunrise, a lower level and higher level. We did the lower level. It was super cold and windy. The sunrise took about 30 minutes or so. They also have park rangers there. There's also a little souvenir shop there where you can watch the sunrise from inside. Probably a lot warmer than standing outside like we did but it was shoulder to shoulder. They do sell some ponchos to keep warm. I always look for shot glasses but unfortunately they didn't sell any. It was mostly pictures, maps, and magnets. Haleakala also has hiking trails and spots to watch the sunset. It was neat to be on the very top of the mountain and see all the different landscapes from rocks, to clouds, to grass, and trees. We also saw some people camping on our way back. There's not very many things to see on Maui since you go to RELAX, but this was definitely a great experience.

We always try to visit every National Park whenever we are near one. The park was beautiful and the drive, while there were curves and sharp turns were not as bad as some we have visited. We purchased a lifetime Senior Pass for $10 since we just became eligible and found out the cost was going up to $80 in August.

Winding roads all the way up and down. But when you get to the top it's worth it. The weather is a bit crazy it was cold 57 degrees and sprinkled around the curved roads. I would recommend this it costs $20 a car load.

If you come to Maui, this is one of the places you must visit. The drive might be a little long and curvy but it is worth it. You can go really early in the morning, or around noon time, it can get covered with clouds really fast between 3-5 PM and this can ruin your views of the mountain and the islands. Access to the park is just $20 per vehicle, and be sure you MAKE A RESERVATION IF YOU WANT TO SEE THE SUNRISE, because access to the park is limited during this early hours.

We have done this trip a few times. You have to reserve your tickets in advance for $1.50. They only allow about 150 cars up there. The park charges $20 a car to get in, however you can use your ticket for 3 days at the seven sacred pools stop on the road to hana. Wear warm clothes and if possible pack witner jacket. Its cold.

Drove up to Haleakala on our own, it was wonderful! 10,023 feet at the summit what a view....a few clouds but could see for miles. The crater reminds me of the Grand Canyon, so many different colors. Got to see Silversword plant ('ahinahina) found only in Haleakala, and a Nene goose & mate(the world's rarest goose) hanging out at the visitor's center parking lot. Really must not miss adventure...for everyone! It does coat $20 per car to get into the National Park.

Wow. Just wow!!! We did a driving tour of Haleakala national park (gypsy driving tour in our own car) and I'm soooo happy we did! The most amazing part is being ABOVE the clouds! Our pictures turned out amazing, we saw a Nene, hiked a tiny bit into the canyon, and stood at the summit over ten thousand feet high! Plan at least 3 - 4 hours to drive up and back depending on how many stops you'd like to make and how much you want to hike. It is $15 to get into the park but you can use the same pass on road to Hana at the sacred pools. It's beautiful to see how you can drive from the beach, to lush rolling hills, to completely dried out desert all in the same drive! Totally WORTH IT!!!!!!!!

We left Kahana at 4 am but should’ve left around 3. We had purchased the $1.50 park fee a couple months in advance on the government website which is a must if you plan on going early for the sunset or you will be turned away. When we arrive at around 6:15 the crowd was already situated but we managed to squeeze in. There is also an observatory park tourist Center to see through big windows. A hush actually falls over the crowd when the sun starts to crest the top. It’s absolutely breathtaking and like being on another planet. The volcanic rocks and area is so different and when you are above the clouds it seems surreal. This is something you should do! The drive back was so pretty and there are so many places to stop for breakfast etc. We just had a picnic at the top after the sun rose. It was an amazing start to a wonderful vacation.

You pay one fee ($25) and can enjoy two very different locations. The first is past Hana at the Oheo Gulch. We love hikes and the bamboo forest and waterfalls are amazing! Most people stick to the Seven Sacred pools and waterfront but the 2 mile hike is amazing. People take this hike for the waterfalls but the bamboo forest is quite something. It was pouring rain when we went and we were soaked to the skin but never got cold. Make sure you take a change of clothing.
Amazing sunrise and so worth the early wake up. $25 to enter the park and you must book a reservation a few weeks in advance. Pack warm clothes

Haleakala National Park is a great place to see Maui in its most raw form. We went to go see the Haleakala Volcano first, paying $15 a person. We were told we could use our ticket (which was really a receipt) for the next 3 days. When we ran across Waimoku Falls the next day, we used to same ticket to enter the park! So two great attractions for $15 a person. Works for me!!

Beware of car sickness! Most reviews ask you to take coffee to watch the sunrise - do just that - bring it up! Don't drink it on the way! The twists and turns had my son throwing up all the way up and down the mountain. There is a vendor who sells hot drinks and breakfast at the foot of the mountain - expensive and unnecessary - $30 for 2 coffees, 2 hot chocolates and 4 croissants and a kid throwing up on his sweatpants :( Not a good way to spend a cold morning waiting for the sun to rise. Was the view worth it? Yes! Especially to be above the clouds... the views were spectacular!

I can’t imagine missing an opportunity to visit Haleakala National Park to learn about volcanoes and look into its crater. You can ride your bike (and enjoy coasting down), hike, or simply enjoy looking into the crater. Pack a sandwich and enjoy the day. And here’s an idea especially for your children: Purchase a “Passport to Your National Parks” book (~$10) and each time you visit a national park, your child can get his passport stamped (get one for yourself too)! For an additional $3.00, purchase a “sticker” that your child can paste into the passport (both available at the top). This inexpensive purchase could turn into a life-long goal for visiting all our beautiful parks. My grandson loves his!

We left our hotel at 330am. It took 90minites to get there. Ten dollars To get enter the park. Make sure you go to the top which is the Summit. It is very very cold. We stayed in the car until 30 minutes before sunrise . It was. Breathtaking . The views around the crater were awesome. Definitely, a must see in Maui. We are going back for sunset.

Most people wrote the reviews for the sunrise and sunset viewings, We unfortunately could not make it to either, We just went up during the middle of the day. The drive was nice, climbs pretty steep pretty fast. Drive carefully on the windy roads and take your time. Took us about 1 hour to get to the top at a moderate pace. Even with motion sickness I was okay(though i did the driving). Once you get to the top the vegetation and stuff changes so it feels like you are on a different planet. Pretty neat. VERY COLD at the top, dont let the sun fool you, and I dont get cold often. Take a blanket or at least a jacket and wear comfortable shoes if you want to walk around. Worth seeing at least once. once at the top it is over 10000 feet. Amazing view. Take pics! $10 fee once you get close to the top about 1/2 or 11 miles left.

If you want to see the sunrise, make sure you book your reservation - its only $1.50. They now limit the number of cars that can go at Sunrise, which makes it a very enjoyable experience. Dress warm - it was 40 and windy when we were there. We arrived around 4 am, so had 2 hours to wait. We went to the topmost point, and talked to a park employee, who informed us that the lookout point below the topmost point was actually the better spot to see the sunrise, then come back up after sunrise. We followed his advice and so glad we did. the tour buses will start dropping everyone off at that lookout, so you have to go claim your spot on the railing for a great view. We lucked out having a nice clear morning!

Listen Harpers Ferry is beautiful and the work they have done on the historic buildings is impressive. But the city and the National Park Service have made their properties almost unreachable because of the ridiculous parking in town. The town forces you to download an app to pay for a parking spot but there's no service in town. The National Park Service makes you pay $10 to park a mile away from all of the important places and take a bus. Literally the parking situation ruined the entire experience for me

I learned so much about Harper's Ferry today. I took a walking self-tour of the area which was much smaller than I imagined. This included the Point, the John Brown Fort and museum, the Whitehall Tavern, the Lewis and Clark exhibit, the ruins of the St. John’s Episcopal Church, and ending with the Jefferson Rock and Harper House. It was $10 to park at the visitor's center with a bus ride to the lower area. Once there I spent about an hour and a half checking out the sites. Plenty of shops and eateries but not much parking there.

We parked at the visitor centre and took the shuttle bus to the lower town as we thought this was the only option but we did see cars driving around the town. There is a $10 entrance fee but it's worth considering the America the Beautiful pass if you are going to be visiting a lot of NPS sites ($80 for 12 months). The shuttle buses seemed to run frequently and stopped at Bolivar Heights before continuing to lower town. In lower town there were some shops and museums on the road where the buses drop you off with facades as they would have been in the 1800s. There's a good book shop. We then had a look up the hill and bought some (what turned out to be very expensive) sweets in the traditional sweet shop. There's a nice view of the river from the church on the hill.

My wife and I spent three days for our 30th anniversary in the Harpers Ferry area. Stayed at the RiverKeeper Inn a few miles from the park and enjoyed the short countryside commute to the park headquarters. The only cost incurred to visit the park was a $10 parking ticket good for 3 days. The shuttle buses, with their friendly drivers, to the historic town and surrounding battlefields were very commodious and free of charge and the recordings explaining the significant sights along the way were very informative. The park employees were very helpful and knowledgeable of the history surrounding the sites. For railroad fans, Harpers Ferry with its numerous bridges across the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers is located at a key pass through the Blue Ridge Mountains and enjoys quite a few train passes every day. Watch them come whistling through the mountain tunnel. We enjoyed this first visit to Harpers Ferry immensely!

The national park is very well taken care of and is a great place to visit. The visitors center is a nice hub and at $10 per car load, won't break the bank. This entitles you to bus transportation to 2 of the historic sites. Beautiful view and a great deal of history.

We stopped here on our way home from Norfolk. It was relatively easy to find and the signage nearby was excellent. There is an admission fee ($10 I believe) but we used our "America the Beautiful" lifetime passes, which are available for only $10 for those 62 and over. The town is nicely preserved/restored and the sites about John Browns raid are nicely interpreted. There are a series of films in the shop across from the fort about the raid and there is a film in the visitors center about the town. We walked the footbridge to Maryland (it was pretty easy) and saw the mid-point of the Appalachian Trail. We also saw the signage about the provisioning of the Lewis and Clark expedition from this site.
Parking is at a premium here and not very many spots to park. Actually you have to use Parkmobile off street and be sure you have downloaded it correctly as we found a $50 parking ticket.

Surrounded by fall foliage a perfect location for a day trip. Bring a picnic as plenty of picnic tables up near the park service parking lot or enjoy lunch at one of the local eateries in town. If lucky you might get a parking spot in town, however on busy days you will need to catch a park bus from the upper lot. Park entry costs $10 per car.

This is a great place to go - especially for those who like to wander and self-guide. Two ways in - drive or take the shuttle. Parking is crazy so I recommend the shuttle. The history is great - there is so much to see - even the first "Billboard" in the US. The display is just great. Everything is well maintained and yet there is so much freedom to explore, go off the sidewalks, wade in the river....it's a great destination or stop along the way. $10 a carload!

The shuttle to Harpers Ferry is the way to go. It's $10 for a car to park but saves you the hassle of trying to park at the Lower Town. Plus it's informative as you are traveling from the lot to the Lower Town.

I had seen photos of Harper's Ferry and it looked like a very scenic spot-- situated between two rivers and between mountains. I love photography and my husband is a bit of a history buff so I thought it would be a great place to visit. The town was very scenic and the river view was terrific. I was hoping to get a good photo of the town like the ones I had seen online. However, when I got there I found out that I had to hike up the mountainside to get the fantastic view that I had seen in photographs. This was not something that I was prepaerd to do --so I was a little disappointed. With that said, I did enjoy our visit to Harper's Ferry. The town is walkable and well preserved. There are plenty of signs explaining the interesting history of the area. I learned quite a few things I didn't know --- including the fact that Lewis and Clark were part of the town's story --as well as its role in the Civil War. There was a foot bridge that allowed you to walk out over the river and enjoy the view from there. I also was surpried that the area was part of the Appalachian Trail --with many hikers crossing the bridge and walking through the town. They have an active railroad there and Amtrak trains were running through the station. If nature is part of the experience you are looking for --there is a nice walking path next to the Shenandoah River. There were people with rubber rafts and kayaks in the water--looked like they were having lots of fun. There were ruins on the shore to explore--even tiny sea shells on the sandy banks. There is a fee to enter the park but we didn't have to pay since my husband has a lifetime Senior Pass ($10.00 for anyone over 62).This fee includes parking --and we were able to find parking easily during our weekday visit. I don't know if this would be true on weekends and during the summer vacation months. While we were visiting there were plenty of school kids visiting, too. Another thing to keep in mind -- the town is on hilly ground---you may have to walk up steps or down steep streets to see some places. However, I think you could explore some of the area without too much steep walking if you needed to avoid it. We walked up the steps near the church and it wasn't too bad --the view back over town was pretty nice. Overall , Harper's Ferry is a nice trip for anyone who is interested in American history --and also enjoys being outdoors in a scenic spot.

Park is great; lava tube, caldera view, and museum. No lava flowing in the park proper when we visited, so on the recommendation of a park ranger we drove around to Kalapana, rented bikes, rode about 4 miles on a gravel road, and the hiked over the lava field to the current flow. Long and rough hike, about 1 hour, but worth the effort. The rental operates 3 to 9 pm. Bikes are 5 to 40 dollars, we negotiated 15 for passable bikes. The rental includes helmet, headlamp, flashlight, poncho and one water bottle. You need additional water. The headlamp and flashlight were essential on the hike back over the lava after the sunset.

No, the flow wasn’t above ground during our visit. No, we didn’t splurge for the $500 pp helicopter tour. And this park was still an amazing adventure! We hiked through the lava fields (take tons of water), hiked a few of the flora trails, and visited the guide center, but the park at night was incredible! Right before dusk, we grabbed a table at the Volcano House and watched as the volcano went from point of interest to fierce beauty and wonder. I MUST go back!

The place is a must visit place. They have lots of activities. The entrance fee is $25 for 4 days. There are lots of activities there. Go for holei sea arc, watch their short movies, go check volcanic steams, Thurston lava tube, hike in volcanic craters and visit Jagger museum. Make sure to go to Jagger museum in the evening to see the lava glow.

Spent two days in Volcano for easy park access. Went the first night to view the glowing crater. Spectacular. Spent next day going down Chain of Craters road. Amazing lava fields and the hike to petroglyphs was otherworldly. Paid $13 for 2 popsicles at concession stand at Sea Arch. Will definitely visit park again next time I can afford to go to Hawaii.

Fantastic place where for a mere $25 you can cruise around and explore at will. There are trails, driving routes, and biking options. You can see all sorts of lava stuff including the flowing lava, the steam vents, lava tubes, and more. Make sure you visit at least partway into night time so you can really see the lava and get the effect - you can see it both up high near the museum's overlook or where down closer to the ocean.

Visited volcano park $25 per car fee, hiked to rim through eerie steam fields, rising steam from holes in the ground. Strong sulfur smell. Hike to rim was great view from distance. The best view was from observatory where you can look down into caldera, leave plenty of time to explore. Wow!

If you are on the Big Island and have never been to a Volcano before take the time to see it. It is not like any other environment I have seen before. It is a 2 hour drive from Kailua-Kona but well worth it. The journey alone is worth the trip. We stopped off at the bird trail on the way, which is a short hike and suitable for children. It cost $20 to get in but worth it for all that you can see and do in the park.
Entrance fee of $25 / car for a week .... very reasonable

This was our destination stop. The drive from kona was well worth it. The 25 dollar park entrance fee was ok but well worth it. Being able to see a lot in the three hours we were there was awesome and very educational. It's a must see and visit

So took group of 14 and all different ages. This is full accessible for most levels and a really informative trip. Bring water and good shoes, lava tube is short but worth seeing. Bring your own flashlight. You could spend half day here. $25 bucks per passenger car to get into park unless state park card member

As a geologist at heart, I have always wanted to see an active volcano. And Kilauea Volcano certainly didn't disappoint! We were really lucky when we went as the lava lake was quite high, and you could see the lava erupting! If you listened really closely, you could even hear it. Absolutely surreal, and a dream come true. A moderate fee of US $20 to enter the park is certainly worth it. Also lots of other things to do there. It was much cooler than expected, so warm clothes are recommended. We drove from Kona to see the volcano, but would stay in Hilo next time to be closer to be able to do more of the other activities and walks around the park.
Cost to get in - $20.00. Be prepared for that.

it costs $25 to enter the park unless your active duty military, then its free. once you get to the observatory you can kinda see inside the crater. and depending on the time can see the lava bubbling.
$20 for a car for a 7 day pass. Unbeatable. The variety of experiences and walks and hikes is superb. Start at the visitor centre as soon as you enter the park.
The caldera had lava bubbling and you could see it from the Jagger museum. $20 per car. Plan to spend 2-3 hours to see all the important stuff.

Pretty exciting to see the source of the newest Hawaiian Island still working and see lava flow, however the air quality when it is active as it has been lately is something to check on before you go. The smoke and gasses emitted "vog" can be bad for you over an extended period. We arrived in evening to lots of this and wondered what we had done! We stayed at KMC military camp which is very reasonable and friendly but our bungalow was "well used". Lots of traffic there. Volcano House is historic, staying price around $250 I think. We moved to Waimea area as the air quality was a problem for us. The Park information is excellent, they do tours from there. It is also a good location to check out Hilo area (about 40 min. away) The elevation changes up and down the mountain can be bothersome for some.

When we were there Kīlauea was active so we had an amazing show. Head there at sunset so the lava glows bright. Unfortunately the crater rim drive was closed when we were there so we missed out on that. Expect to pay around $20US entry.

Had a great visit here yesterday - got to see lava craters, lava fields, hike through a crater - something for everyone. You can see the start attractions on one full day of you are reasonably fit and move fast. Otherwise I'd recommend two full days to do absolutely everything. $20 entry for a car for a seven day pass.

$20 per car and your ticket lasts for 7 days, pretty cool.About 3 miles drive to the volcano ,can't see much in the day, so it's better to check put the glow at night. There's steam vents and all kinds of volcano things. You would think its warm because of the lava but no, super cold,and rainy because of the volcano :)

We greatly enjoyed this trip. It cost $20 per vehicle to enter the park. That's good for 7 days. Beyond that, everything we did was free and we wouldn't do it any other way. Stop by the first information center off to the right when you enter the park. The rangers are very helpful in planning your day based on what you want to see and do. The rangers provided free hour-long walking tours throughout the day-that was informative and fun. Our favorite thing we did was hike through Kīlauea Iki Crater. It's about 4 miles round trip, but well worth it for the views. We stayed after dark to see the lava glow by the Jagger Museum-be prepared, a lot of people do this. The lava glow was underwhelming on the day we went, not much to see. The level changes all the time, and the park rangers monitor the level so you'll know if it will be good or boring. They can also tell you how to see lava outside of the park, we went to the end of hwy 130 and rented bikes to see lava flowing into the ocean (do that if you can!!).

This national park is truly a treasure. We have visited many times in the past 30 years and this was the first time we were able to view the lava lake in Halema'uma'u crater. The drive is well worth it. If you have a member of your party who is over 62 you can purchase a lifetime pass for $10 good for 4 entries at a time. Definitely a must see!
This is a must see on the big island. $20 per car for week's pass is a super value. Plan on spending a lot of time, drive to the end, see the lava flow at night.
I go back often to the Big Island just in hopes of getting close to some real Lava. Almost did last trip but it was flowing on private land and just could not pay $200 for a "tour"

Driving from kona via road 160 part of the way, not so nice road. Then changed to road 11 this was really good. Because long way to volcano, just about 100 mi. At the entrence have to pay 20$ for what ? Anyway there was just smoke in volcano no really lava as on all pictures. We had a nice long trip to volcano.
It costs $20 to get in to the national park.

We planned on visiting for part of a day but there was so much to do we had to come back. Fortunately Park Admission is good for more than one day. You really must see the crater after dark to appreciate the lava. The museum near the crater is very educational and worth driving to see.. We enjoyed walking in the lava tubes. Our son completed the little book for his ranger badge and learned a great deal.

This National Park is amazing. You really need more than one day there. We spent a little more than a day and half there and still did not get to see everything we wanted to see. The drive down Chain of Craters Road is fascinating as is the Thurston Lava Tube. We also did the Kilauea Iki Trail Hike. It is four miles roundtrip and took us about 3 hours to do. We stopped along the way for pictures. I would highly recommend buying the trail guide for this hike at the gift store in the Visitors' Center. It is only $2 and added a lot of interesting facts to what we were seeing while hiking. We also were able to attend a Ranger 1 mile hike as soon as we got there. Another item I would highly recommend. It gave us a good background while on the rest of our hikes/site seeing during our trip. Of course, the highlight is the actual caldera. The first day we were there you could see the lava spurting up a little bit during the day which we were told is highly unusual. We went both nights to see it and that was spectacular. Each night was slightly different so I'm glad we went twice. The lava and the glow was much more visible at night. Unless you have a really good camera, the pictures don't do it justice. I can't wait to go back here again.

This place is really why people come to the Big Island. It costs $20 to enter the park by car. Start at the Visitor Centre for some basic information then cross the road to Volcano house for your first view of the crater. The house itself houses eating places and a gift store but is a lovely old homestead in itself. Then drive to the Jagger museum. This is as close as you can get on a short trip for some great shots. We saw the moulten lava leaping up in the distance. Do take a long lens camera and a jacket as there is more than a 25 degree Farenheit difference between Kona and the mountain. Many years ago it was possible to get closer by car. Take a look at the steaming bluffs and the Thurston lava tube while you are there. All this will take a couple of hours. There are also hiking options if you have longer but you need to be well prepared to carry 3 litres of water and wear good walking shoes.

A definite must for Big Island Vacation. First, buy the app that is like a GPS activated tour guide, its $3 and worst it. Next go to the Kilauea crater last and take your pics, evening is good for the glow. Makes sure you walk thru Thurston lava tube, its quick and awesome, kid friendly. Across the road it the hike to Kilauea iki crater which is about an hour of work walking down and back up but its a dormant lava lake surrounded by lush jungle. The crater drive goes thru a bunch of natural pits but the best it as the end where the natural land bridge is and the end of the road where the new lava is spewing into the ocean. As of today its a 7 mile round trip along the emergency road. There is a little stand that sells water.

What an amazing park, with so many 'must see' sites and hiking trails. We weren't able to see everything in one day, so if you can plan for two! The park appears to be very well managed and maintained, and the Rangers were helpful and knowledgeable without being 'babysitter' types I have seen at other parks. We paid $20 for the car pass, good for multiple days. A definite highlight of Hawaii!
The view was high on a mountain, that was the only cool part. Tons of places were blocked off so we had to turn around. It was not worth the $20 at the gate. Go find your own mountain and hike it :)

My partner and I did a helicopter tour (with doors on) over the volcano and although quite expensive ($200 odd usd per person) for 1 hour helicopter flight, it was one of the best things that I have ever done. Flying over the crater, seeing live neon orange lava flow down the crater, see steam arise and all paired with national geographic amazing music. Wow wow wow!!! I was absolutely mind blown by the colour, the steam, the heat and the sheer force. Nothing like I had imagined. Spend the money, it's a once in a lifetime experience that you will never forget. Simply mind-blowing, unreal and hard to comprehend.
Beautiful variety of natural wonders to see-- lava fields, craters, jungle, coastline, and dessert. $20/car gets you a one-week pass.
We visited the park twice in the same week thanks to the 7 day entry provided within the $20 per car price.

Depending on where you are staying, getting to the Volcano National Park can be a drive, for us staying on the other side of the island, it was about a 2 hour drive. Be sure to check the weather before because even when it was sunny and hot on the other side of the island, it could be cold at rainy at the park. If you are over 62, there is a lifetime senior pass you can buy for only $10 that will get you into any national park.

Went with my wife, 8month old son and 3 year old daughter. I was very disappointed when I was there cause I just drove 2 hrs to watch lava but the crater just ended blowing tiny bits smoke. I've seen more action in a steam sauna. Kinda pissed I spent $15 to see that. The only reason I gave them 3 stars is because the lava tubes were a site to see.

With 2 kids under 7 hiking is not on our to do list BUT we were able to walk through the Nanuka lava tube (easy walk with a few stairs), walked between lava tube n kilauea iki lookout (15min each way) happily enough. Raincoats r a MUST as are shoes that can get dirty. We stopped at the steam vents n Jaggar Museum bt unfortunately the clouds were sitting on us n we didnt see much. We got the $25 3 park pass so we will go back to see if we can see lava glow in better weather. Easy drive out from Hilo. We planned it as afternoon activity 3-7pm to time seeing lava glow, was good timing :)

It is a national park so the is a fee. I believe it was $15 and was good for a week. There is a visitor center with lots of information about volcanos and the surrounding area close to the entrance. As you continue up to the crater there is another visitor center. Very informative and you can have a guide who will give history and information about the crater. You can also do some hiking and go in a lava tube. Lots of easy hiking trails.

This park is well worth the $15. An absolute must see if you go to the big island. We didn't do much hiking this time, but will when we return next time. Still, the things you see by car are amazing and it is worth taking once of the short ranger-led hikes. I have never been to another park with so much enthusiasm and expertise shown by the Rangers. Wonderful national park!

We hired a car for our stay on Hawaii and visited the National Park. The visitors centre provides pamphlets and has guides to answer queries so it is very easy to visit without doing a tour. It is $15 entry per vehicle and valid for 5 days. We did a short walk from the visitors centre to Volcano House Hotel and had a coffee and admired the view and went on a walk to the steam vents from there and returned via the Sulphur banks. Then we drove round to Thurston Lava Tube. There are various short walks or longer walks depending upon what takes your fancy. We did the Chain of Craters Road which I recommend. It is 61kms return and there are various points of interest to stop. The Ranger at the end of the road was very informative and he pointed out Nene there. This drive took a couple of hours but that will depend on the number of stops and how far one wants to walk. Upon our return we went to the Jaggar Museum and outlook. The Museum was interesting. This was the point where we watched and waited for nightfall to watch the night glow. Definitely recommend staying for that - incredible sight. We managed to find our way around with the maps provided and only had the one day here. We found this sufficient time although would recommend staying overnight in Volcano if you can so as to avoid a drive at night, in our case back to Kona. The road is a typical NZ country road, not a 4 lane highway like many may be used to so care is required.
Best $15 ever spent! We drove from Kona, checked in at the visitor center. There is a lot of information in side. A ranger announced a hike leaving in five minutes so we went on the

Do not miss this - daytime AND nighttime. During the day the smoke is visible from Halemaumau, walked Thurston lava tube and drove down chain of craters road to the ocean and sae the sea arch. At night you can see the glow of the lava from the observatory. In awe at the power of nature. If over 60 - get a National Park pass before you go - $10 for lifetime use!

Just got back from visiting volcano national park and it was amazing. At first I was not real excited to go but once we saw the steam vents, the calderas, the sulfur banks and hiked through the lava tube I was impressed. If we had more time and were better prepared a hike down to the base of the volcano would have been impressive. Well worth the 15 dollars admission fee.

What a unique place to go. We went for a whole day and then came back later. Park pass is good all over the Island for a week! Well worth the $15 per car admission. The least expensive and most memorable thing we did. Visited the center, drove around part of the rim and then walked to the Thurston lava tube and down on to Kilauea Iki crater. Walked right out onto the floor! Turned around and there, across the crater was the most awesome rainbow. You could see it all the way from one end on the ground to the other! This is a must do for your "bucket list". Then, as if it could be topped, we went and looked at the glow of the volcano in the dark at the Jagger Center. Way, too cool!

Remember that as of June1, the new entrance fee is $15, but it is worthit. Figure on a full day of visiting and plan your trip inside the park before you arrive. There is so much to see and do. You will need sturdy shoes, sun screen, and plenty of water. Rangers lead tours all day long and there is something for everyone. The "up and down" tour starts at the visitors' center and takes you to the crater floor. Plan for 2 hours for this ranger-led tour. Food is available at the lodge, but it is pricey. Beautiful views of the crater inside the Volcano House. Comfortable seats to sit and relax and enjoy the view.

Only cost $20 for my husband and I to enter the park which we didn't think was too bad especially when it was a pass good for the whole week. The views were spectacular! The one female ranger talked to everyone about the current conditions in the park and was very informative. The only downside was that there were a lot of people from tour buses there and it got pretty crowded at some place (but that's not the parks fault). The drive down to the sea arch on the coast was my favorite, it was breathtakingly beautiful.

Cannot say enough wonderful things about this place. First of all they only charge you $10 per whole car load to get in, then there is so much to see and do from the fantastic Jaggar museum and the view of the lava, to the steam vents, lava tubes, sulphur ponds and the wonderful park staff. Wow, what a place, it's a Must do place

I first visited the park as a kid in 1988 and was lucky enough to see several lava flows and a lava tube emptying into the sea. No accessible flows this time around, but it did not disappoint. Seeing the writhing, Giger-esque Pahoehoe lava formations again brought back all of the imagination and awe. The main Caldera was closed to pedestrian access because of high sulphur dioxide concentrations, but the 4-mile hike through the nearby inactive Kilauea Iki crater was outstanding. Weather is unpredictable, which makes a $2 poncho a good investment.

If you are planning to go to the Big Island then Hawaii National Park is a must see attraction. It stays opens 24/ 7. You only have to pay the parking fee $15.00 for cars. The views of the live lava was not visible but we enjoyed the whole experience. We only spend half a day at the park. I suggest one full day. At night the view of the live crater was different than the day time- red glowing like fire but during the day, we only saw the smoke. We did the small Hike of Halemuamua Trail. At the end of the trail we saw Steam Vents, Steaming Bluff, and Ha‘akulamanu - Sulphur Banks. They were amazing as the day was cold and windy around the Steam Vents it was warm. When we came out of the forest/ vegetation, there was a rainbow to welcome us. WOW! At night we saw the lava from Jaggar Museum. Have Plenty of food and drinks with you and if we are planning the trip in winter months have winter clothes - coat, hats and gloves with you. It gets really cold around evenings.

We drove from Kona to the volcano nat'l park, it's about 100 miles in one direction but the drive alone is worth it. Gorgeous coastal views along the way. Once there, there's a $10 per car fee for the park. There's a great restaurant overlooking the crater. Go to the observatory, steam vents and the lava tube. If you have 2-3 more hours hike down into the crater. Absolutely gorgeous.
It was a great half day trip, less than an hour from Hilo the Volcano National Park has an entry fee of only $10.00 per car.

$10 buys you as many visits to this national park as you like for 7 days. Lava landscapes and night skies filled with stars. Even a short visit is a memorable one. A morning hike out to the crater bed was well worth the journey. Note path to crater bed best done during light, but trail is well groomed (even for hubby with bad knee and son feeling sick from a very bad cold).

This is a review for viewing the lava flow from the county side, Halapana, and not from The National Park side. We drove from Kailua-Kona to 7 mile before Hilo then had another 22 miles to Halapana. This took about 3 1/2 hours of driving. Once at the end of the road there were many vendors renting bicycles. We chose one that had many bicycles to choose from at a flat rate of $20. They came with lights for the bicycles, headlamp, a bicycle lock and a medical kit. They were very nice. They take credit cards. It is about 3 1/2 to 4 mile bicycle ride or hike to the end of the gravel road to where you park your bike. The bike ride had a few small hills but you won't have any problems if you're in somewhat decent shape. We made in about 25 minutes. From there it is an easy five minute walk over domed styled lava (vs the sharp edged lava) to the viewing area. The area to view is about 1/4 mile from where the lava enters the ocean. It is a once in a lifetime opportunity and must not be missed. The best part is when you wait till the sun goes down to capture all the beauty. Riding back in the dark was a bit difficult and some people were walking bikes. It was then another 3 1/2 hours drive back to Kona. People told us that night that the National Park Service was telling them to come to the county side because there was so much smoke from the park side. The prevailing winds tend to blow northwards. There are no bike rentals from the park side and the hiking is 5 miles each way over very difficult terrain. It was a long day for sure, but would definitely recommend viewing the lava flow from the county (Hilo) side. Mahalo.

We've been here twice before but not when the lava was flowing so imagine our surprise when we stopped at the Jagger Museum and saw steam and lava bubbling up. It was so exciting but believe me it does not compare to taking a boat tour with Lava Ocean Tours and getting up close and personal with the lava. It was awesome, fantastic and a once in a lifetime experience. We drove chain of craters road as before but this time we used an app called Shaka Hawaii so we stopped at a Crater we didn't know existed and there's no signage either! This app is $4 and totally worth it. Always thrilling to visit just more so this time with the lava flowing.

Lava tubes big enough to walk through, active craters, rich history, a great value at $5 - or free for locals. Admission is good for a week also, in case you can't see all the sights in one day. I recommend multiple visits or a full day because some parts are best seen during the day while the large active crater is best seen glowing at night.
The hikes and driving tours are amazing be sure to visit the museum and clear a full day to take in everything. Well worth the 10 dollar parking charge.

We arrived at the visitor center around noon. We first proceeded to drive down to the ocean to see the Holei Sea Arch. On the way there, it was nice to see the change in vegetations from rain forest to barren earth with lava rocks all around you. The sea arch as well as the entire coastline are quite impressive to see. There are bathroom facilities as well as a booth at the end of the road that sells snacks and memorabilia. We then drove back up and parked at the Lava Tube. There, we began our counter clock-wise hike around the crater rim. We took everyone's advice and got on the Hilauea Iki trail, which is beginner to intermediate level. We did not purchase the $2 brochure like most people did, simply because we did not have any dollar bills on us (an oversight on our part). We did, however, stop at the Volcano House for a light lunch, about a mile into the hike. The view at the restaurant was simply breathtaking. After our light meal, we continued our hike on the Kilauea Iki trail and descended down to the crater. It was raining off and on, and the trail was a bit muddy and slippery, but it didn't really bother us. The plants and fowls along the way kept us intrigued. When we finally got down to the crater, we spent some time taking in the scenery there.
