The feeling standing at the bottom of the crater with fresh lava rocks and steam coming out of the earth can only be described as surreal. The ascend back up to the Lava Tube did not take long at all. Overall, we spent 6 hours at the park, and we highly recommend it.

The trip in to the park is through a moonscape of lava flows with lots of pullouts and interpretive signage. We drove from Kona and loved the well maintained winding road. The park itself is only $10 for a week pass, and excellent value for a very educational experience. We heard 2 very knowledgeable guides, one on a tour of Devastation Trail, the other at the Jagger Museum. Stay for the evening and see the glow - it was great even in the rain.

Me and my fiance decided to visit the Volcanoes National Park during our stay on Big Island. We visited on a day when we were attempting to drive around the entire island. So, our visit here was pretty brief. But I am so happy we decided to venture into the park. We drove up to Jagger Museum and the lookout point into the caldera is amazing. Our next stop was the Thurston Lava Tube and this is a very shory hike in a canopy shadded area. So it was nice and cool. This is well worth the drive into the park and for the $10 per car cost even if you only see these two things. There are also various craters you can see on the Crater Rim Drive which we did and abbreviated version of as we were in somewhat of a hurry.

For $10 you get a full day of activities. There's tons of hiking through desert, rainforest and into volcanic sites. There's no access to active lava! The only way to see that is by air. You can see the volcano glowing after dark though so its definitely worth coming back after 7pm.

The Park is sensational with access to world class landscapes for $10 for a car for a week. We took an introductory guided tour which was unexpectedly brilliant. Our guide explained flora, tectonic history and Hawaiian mythology and showed us an interesting part of the crater. Go early morning to Chain of Craters road and you can have it pretty much to yourself. It's breathtaking! Car parks get busy later in the day with lazy tourists in cars and tour buses but venture a few feet from the key sites and you literally have the park to yourselves. Halemaumau crater at night is worth a visit after dinner if you stay close enough.
Took a day trip from Hilo to the Volcano National Park. SInce it is a run by the Park Service it is only $10 for a car of people and the pass is valid for a week.

Very interesting, lots of information. If you want to see the park be willing to take a long hike, make sure you have the proper shoes (not flip flops)water, a snack, a camera, and a jacket. You can walk over lava for a close up look at the devastation. The park never closes and you pay for a pass ($5.00) that is good for the week.
Stopped by here on a nice afternoon. Visitor Center is nice and the rangers go out of their way to help you. You can pick apples here, 1 is free or they are $1/#.

Camped for 2 night, price was reasonable ($10 for primitive site). There was no shower on site but we get to have hot shower at the one of the bathhouse. Very different from the typical national park, cute little town to spend a weekend. Remember to bring some bottles to take some hot springs water home!

We stumbled upon this park last minute and we’re glad we did! It’s in such a beautiful natural rustic setting close to Santa Fe! We hit it just right for the fall foliage. The most gorgeous scenery I’ve ever laid my eyes on. Go to the top of the mountain and pay the money to ride tram to the top! It’s $15 a person but so worth it for the pics you’ll have. Great place for camping or picnicking which we did. Get off the beaten path and do this:-)

The waterfall hike is less than a mile round trip and beautiful. If you are in for a challenge, try the 3 mile circle trail for an excellent view of the city (lots of switchbacks). It only costs $5 to park and be among the evergreen trees only a few miles for the desert.
Go early to get your free tickets for Independence Hall. Tickets are free but you need them. No tickets? Not a problem, you can still see the Liberty Bell and several other buildings.
Lots of national history here spread over several floors and lots of tactile interaction. Cost to enter but well worth it. Very interesting and well laid out.

We reserved a spot online to see Independence Hall for $6 for a family of 4 at the 12:45 time slot on Saturday, April 29th. It was recommended to pick up our tickets 45 min early, which we did and we breezed through security. There was actually room on the 12:30 tour so we went with the earlier group. This is a brief but informative tour led by a Park ranger. We got to see the room where the Declaration of Independence and Constitution were signed and it was awesome to experience those pieces of history. Even my 6 & 9yr old liked it- the tour was not too long where kids get antsy.
This is quit a display just for a bell. But, it is not just any bell. This is a great exhibit and it is a National Park. And it is free admission, paid for with our tax dollars. Go see it.

Really, you must make this visit if you are in Philadelphia. There are several attractions to go and see and several more gems in the area. Be sure to reserve tickets for Independence Hall as it is a Ranger led program, tickets are only $1.50 when purchased online. Get ready to go through some metal detectors too, security is required before seeing the Liberty Bell or going into Independence Hall. In the area, don’t forget to visit the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.
Buy water from the guy on the street! He sells it for $1 a bottle. We passed him up, and ended up paying $3 a bottle elsewhere.

Independence Historical Park contains many important and interesting sites, most of which are free. The only three sites my family visited that cost money are National Constitution Center, Betsy Ross House, and Christ Church Burial Ground. I know that Christ Church itself and the Ben Franklin Museum cost money as well: there may be others I do not know about. Regardless, the vast majority are free. If you wish to reserve tickets for Independence Hall, there is a $1.50 processing fee: it is worth it as tickets do run out.

Upon our arrival to Philly we came directly to the Visitor Center which worked out well. You park underneath the building and can stay all day as there is a great deal to see. We watched one of the free films, read exhibit information, picked up maps and paid for the trolley tour. Tickets were not available for Independence Hall as we arrived in the afternoon. Across the street we walked in to see the Liberty Bell and there was not a line as it was Friday afternoon. When we came back on Sunday (over Memorial Day) the rest of the family had to wait about a half hour. We also visited the US Mint, The Franklin Museum($5) and Reading Terminal for lunch before going to City Hall's Spray Park which was a few blocks away.

Very good tour of independence hall. Tickets are free and wait time was not bad, ( in the a.m.) tour guides were very knowledgeable and put an interactive perspective on the experience without gearing the tour towards children.

long security wait, poor layout and history panels for kids, Liberty Bell poor presentation and lighting, park area difficult to gert to and leave from, bathrooms are disgusting and for the USA very poor to all nationalities. Expected MORE for tax $ better by much 25=years ago

Took the 90 minute Scenic Tour.  Great experience with our guide, Brad. Worth the $12 fee. There are lots of up and down stairs to climb. About 750 steps in all, so one must be reasonably fit and mobile. All have handrails (Wear gloves as the metal gets cold in the damp 49° temperatures.) The tours run on  schedule, so don't expect to just show up and hop on a tour. If on a schedule or traveling with impatient children, call ahead to find out tour times for the day. There are  couple spots were it is not allowed to carry a child that can walk, so make sure your kids are up for the journey. In that case, the shorter 30 minute tour may be best.

This was a great cave to see cool rock and column formations. There were metal stairs and cement paths so it was not difficult to tour and many people of all ages in our group. Ranger Jerob was educational and funny. For only $12 tour fee, definitely a must-do.
We did the 90 minute Scenic Tour. $12 per person. Lots of stairs but not too strenuous. Very informative.

Having been to several caves, this one is quite amazing. Teenager liked it... Even the three year old thought it was cool. Worth the time and $$$. Would love to do a longer tour if I didn't have a preschooler with us.

I had never been on a cave tour prior to this trip but it was very cool! We did the scenic tour which was $12 for adults and a hour and a half. Its 49 degrees Fahrenheit all year round they suggest proper clothes and footwear. Some areas are slippery. At one point in the tour we were 300 some feet underground. The tour guide was very friendly and knowledgeable. I learned a lot and had a great time.

Jewel Cave is the 3rd largest cave in the world. It is over 180 miles long and 208 ft deep. At one point you will be at the 208 foot depth. The cave has a elevator to the bottom. The scenic tour will be around 1 1/2 hrs. It has over 700 steps, and you do go up and down. The ranger takes his time so everyone can keep up. If you have heart or mobility problems, this is not for you. They have other shorter tours available. We are seniors, and we did take this scenic tour @ a cost of $12 ea. It is a little chilly, so wear a light jacket. Wear some sort of light leather gloves, as the aluminum railings are damp with dew and can be slippery. You are asked to hold on to the railings going up and down the steps. We were glad to be informed of this before we went. This cave has a very interesting history and one is amazed on how it was discovered and explored. There was construction going on in the parking lot, but we did not have a problem. I would also go early in the morning as to avoid the rush. This is the cave to visit, versus Wind cave.

I've toured a lot of caves and this was a pretty good cave especially for just $12. Take a jacket because it stays pretty cold in there! Make sure you wear you're walking shoes! Lots of stairs! We weren't able to tour Wind Cave but the people that had toured Wind Cave already said this was the better cave.

We took Scenic Tour: 1 hr 20 min; $8/adult; 723 steps; 1/2 mile; "moderately strenuous". We even took turns carrying my 30+ pound granddaughter, and it wasn't that bad. You must make this a part of your Black Hills experience!

Passing through on Hwy 26, we briefly detoured into the monument and stopped in at the visitor center. We had never even heard of the fossil beds and after touring the center had to return to the highway, but our interest has been captured and we will soon make another visit and spend the time it deserves! A truly fascinating location.
park: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument

text: Make sure to watch the movie. It gives you a real feel for the power of the flood, how fast and furious and devastating it was. From the visitors' center and the trails there are great views of what was once the lake. At $4.00/adult, it's a bargain. I would also recommend taking the short drive to the clubhouse and a couple other member "cottages". The clubhouse was closed for the season when we visited so we couldn't go inside, but it was interesting to compare the present-day lay of the land to the photos of the clubhouse right at the lakeshore. What a different perspective.

This park is amazing. You pay $25 for a seven days visit. You can drive around and stop from time to time to enjoy a hiking trail. The boulders formation are breath taken. Don't miss the skull trail. You also can camp there. Several gorgeous camping sites. Reservation required.

This was our first visit to Joshua Tree National Park and there were several things that delighted us. The trees themselves were quite charming, although we found out that they are not trees at all but related to lily plants.There are no circular rings across the trunks. Secondly, the trees were in blossom. Not even people who live nearby get to see the blossoms very often. Thirdly, we were totally surprised by the rock formations. There are many of them - not mountains exactly, but more like piles of large rocks strewn from a giant's bucket. And when we were leaving near sunset, the fading sunlight highlighted several mountain ranges. Another pleasant surprise was that we were able to buy a lifetime senior pass to the national parks for $10.00 instead of having to pay $25.00 for a single day's entrance fee.

We drove from Palm Springs to the Joshua Tree entrance off of Hwy 62. It was easy to find and and the entry fee for one vehicle was $20.00. Immediately, you notice the Joshua tres and boulders. There are plenty of areas to stop and hike, take pictures and climb rocks. We travelled south to exit the park at Cottonwood entrance. As you travel south, you see less Joshua trees so I am glad we entered the park at the other location.

This place is breathtaking! So glad I decided to spend some time here while passing through Indian Wells. I recommend giving yourself at least a half day to explore, longer if you can. I witnessed a spectacular sunset, and have heard the stars are worth staying overnight to see. It takes about 2 hours to drive through the whole park (if you're not hiking), day fees are $20 cash. I believe you can stay overnight for that price and it's good for 7 days.

I am very happy that such natural beauty in its diversity is preserved and protected for all to enjoy. We spent 4 days visiting the park. Every thing is clearly marked. We were there when the Joshua trees were in bloom. We paid $20 to enter (vehicle fee) and it was good for a week. Most of the staff in the office were friendly and helpful and some were abrupt.

This national park, a couple hours south of L.A., is a definitely a place to visit, explore and you won't be disappointed. You pay $20 to enter the park with a vehicle and the pass is good for 7 days! So, that's a major plus. There are plenty of places to have picnics, tons of trails, we heard packs of coyotes howling in the early morning, we saw plenty of wildlife and the weather was perfect in February when we went. At night, the stars seemed to be closer and so big and bright. The silence is what I enjoyed the most. Being able to stand there and not hear cars, horns, other people and just hear the sound of the desert was a reward, at least for me, in itself. I can't wait to go back,

Beautiful scenic drive if you start at the Joshua Tree Visitors Center to Cottonwood. Be sure to visit Keyes View to see the Cochella Valley, Salton Lake, and San Andreas Fault. Go in the morning when the air is clear and be sure you have a full tank of gas and plenty of water as you are pretty much in the middle of nowhere. Keyes Point is wheelchair accessible, but its a very steep hill to have to push a wheelchair up and I'm not sure how a motorized scooter would do... The geologic formations are spectacular, breathtaking views of the valley, lots of places to stop the car and take it all in and get pics. There were restrooms fairly frequently along the way, which s not common in many parks of these types so that was a plus. I'm not a hiker or camper so I can't speak to those aspects. If you like nature, landscapes, and scenery, you won't want to miss this. It's a $15 park entry fee, which I thought was rather steep, but free for active military with the annual park pass.

I drove through Joshua Tree National Park with my husband and it was worth the trip. I've never seen a place like this, vast and eerily quiet. There are many picnic areas throughout the park, it's worth it to pack a picnic and make a day out if it. Another great thing: the 15$ entrance fee is good for a week, so you can always go back if you're in the area. Even if you don't, a one time trip is well worth the 15$.

This was the second time I've taken the Kalaupapa mule ride to the peninsula and had the Damian tour. The scenery going down and at the bottom is spectacular. The view of the Pali sea cliffs that rise 2000 is breathtaking. I think this is one of the most beautiful scenic views in Hawaii. The mule ride is a bit strenuous and takes about 1 1/2 hours to get down and an hour up but anyone in reasonable health can do it. A delicious lunch is provided at the bottom. The story of the leper colony and those who worked there is inspirational. The cost was about $230 but well worth it. This should be a must for anyone visiting Molokai but plan ahead because the number of visitors per day is limited. We had a great guide with Damian tours who was very knowledgable about everything about Kalaupapa.

We saw as much wildlife in the few hours on our Kenai Fjords Tour as we did on the rest of our 10 day cruise! I went on the 9 hour tour in 2001 and loved it, so chose this company again, and loved it again. Saw 3 transient orcas, 4 humpbacks, horned and tufted puffins, sea lions, hundreds of gulls, sea otters, starfish, and a harbor seal at Holgate glacier. Also really appreciate the affordable coffee and chocolate chip cookie on board. $2 coffee or $8 refillable car cup - thank you!

The actual day boat ride was long, cold, and boring. We had never been to Alaska, never seen whales or glaciers. We actually did see whales, but at the time I really didn't think it was so exciting. We saw a couple of whale tails waving at us, and some other birds. The prime rib and Alaska King Crab which is half of the reason we bought this tour was really bad. The Crabs were cold, with some ice still on the inside and the prime rib was tasteless. In fact the Alaska King Crab legs we buy at Costco's was better and the prime rib all you can eat at Golden Corral was better.

I went on the 9 hour Kenai Fjord/Northwest Glacier tour and it was outstanding. While the cost was high--almost $200--it was worth the money, experience and memories. I'd recommend this experience as a must for anyone visiting Seward.

We had a difficult time finding parking. The overflow lot had a few openings but if you're handicapped, it will be a difficult walk. Crossing at the light is strange as well. Traffic is heavy and drivers don't watch very well with all the walkers. The 35 minute video is well worth the time as is the museum. You can walk up the mountain or drive. The gift shop is well stocked with loads of history choices. Prices are affordable. So glad we had the opportunity to learn more about the civil war in the Atlanta area. Nicely done!

So many wonderful trails with beautiful spots to see the city. One of the best kept secrets in Kennesaw it's ideal for kids walking your dogs and just enjoying a run on the many trails around the mountain. Stop in the visitors center off old 41 and get a map. You can also take the bus to the top of the mountain on the weekend for $3.

Just about the favourite of my whole trip, the General Grant Grove. Well worth spending longer here, I had to cut it short, big regret. Bought an annual pass so I can return. $80 for a year of one car entry is cheap and you can do every park in the USA on that spend.

Went in a Sportsmobile Van which sits, I think, pretty high off the ground. Having gone over the side of a mountain road (not MY driving) before made me very uncomfortable in this trek up the road. It was very sad to see so many trees dying from the lack of water and infestation of bark beetles. On the way to Boyden Cave, I could see over the side of the road and into the deep, deep, valley below. It was very scary for me, so I had had enough. I couldn't go to the Roaring River Falls nor the Zumwalt Meadow. But, the river flowing was a beautiful, welcome sight. I can imagine what the river would be like had there been more snowfall and/or rain. On the way back, stopped at the General Grant Grove. The trees are massive! The fire scars on the trees show how the redwoods survived. I'll be taking my car and driving when I return to approach the park from the southern Sequoia side. BTW, I had purchased the Senior Pass several years ago, and there was no charge to enter here.

Beautiful little 1.5 mile loop hike. Trail is fairly easy and on a paved path with plenty of benches to stop and rest if you need but bring your own water. Dogs are allowed, just must be on a leash. The trail head says to go counter clockwise but if you go clockwise you go downhill on the "big" hill instead of uphill (might be helpful to some). Also by going clockwise you'll come up to the big, main sites first. Make sure you stop in the visitors center to get your National Park cancellation for your Park Passport Book. Also make sure you ask for the "special" stamp

Firstly, the park rangers at the station were so very helpful and kind. As with many people, we don't carry a lot of cash anymore and didn't think to bring any for the park fee. We had $9 of the $10 fee. They saw us sitting in our car talking and came out to us in the wind and rain and told us "We'd hate for you to miss out on this." That was before they knew we even had $9.

Southern Indiana isn't on any "Top 10" lists as far as tourism goes, but a trip here as part of the greater "Lincoln Trail", which includes sites in KY and IL was one of the best things we ever did for our kids. A couple of days ago we took our grandkids here, and they loved it as much as their Mom did 25 yrs. ago. This is a quiet park with a lovely living history exhibit showing how the Lincoln family lived when he was young. There's a wonderful building with exhibits, outdoor trails and other tourist sites nearby. Cheap prices, unspoiled nature, few crowds, it's just a gem. And well worth your time.

Tour of the home was informative and surrounding homes are also interesting to walk around. The visitors center has two theaters, one showing Lincoln's before becoming President, and the other is a virtual tour of the Lincoln home. Parking is $2/hr, but the home, visitors center, and park are free admission.

Great place for a quick visit. You only pay for parking at $2 an hour. Park Ranger Sue was very personable and made the tour enjoyable. You can be in and out of here in about 1.5-2 hours so if you have small kids, it is a quick visit. Enjoyed the architecture and the grounds as well as Lincoln's home itself. It is beautifully renovated and preserved. A nice stop on a longer trip.

We didn't plan a whole day in the area, but this was the perfect stop. The parking fee was $2 and the tour through Lincolns home was free. It was a little crowded in the house during the tour, but the ranger giving the tour was friendly and gave interesting information that helped personify the Lincoln family. Very good trip!!

It had been decades since I last visited the Lincoln Home & it is now part of a whole multi building historic dedicated (streets closed to traffic) area. There is a parking fee of $2 in the adjacent lot but you could choose to park on the regular business streets. You enter via the Visitors Center & get a FREE ticket to enter the historic district. It includes a ranger guided tour of the Lincoln Home. The ranger kindly took a picture of our group for us, too. There are other buildings available to enter unguided & we toured the traditional vegetable garden some local volunteers maintain. Sounds like they hope to add more activities or tours/displays in the future so I'll have to keep returning to check it out.

Lincoln's home is the only home that President Abraham Lincoln was to ever own. Walk in the neighborhood where Lincoln, his wife and children lived. There is a short movie in the visitor center that is worth seeing and it is free of charge, as is the home tour. There are several other homes in the neighborhood that can be toured. A small gift shop is located in the tourist center. Tickets are assigned a time and tour groups are small. Show up early and if you have to wait, go across the street to Mr. Linclon's Souvenirs where the prices are a bargain. Then head over to Van's for a cup of coffee and a scone or breakfast sandwich. Linclon's Home has been beautifully restored with some original pieces. As you walk up the stairs to the second floor and grasp the hand rail, you are grasping the same hand rail that Lincoln used. There is reasonable and ample parking onsite. Located across the street is Van's Coffee, a historic house that was moved to the present location. Just next next is Obed and Isaac's, a great microbrewery where you can grab lunch or dinner before heading off to your next stop. Dine inside or outside on nice days.

Surreal to be in Lincoln's house. It's about 85% original, including the furnishings. There is no charge, but a free ticket is required for the guided tour. Visitors may only gain admission to the house with a tour. The tickets can be obtained at the nearby visitor's center. Robert Lincoln sold the house to the State of Illinois for a couple of dollars with a couple of caveats. First, that the State would maintain it and second, that they would never charge an entrance fee. This is a MUST SEE when visiting Springfield. I would place it at the top of the list.

National Parks is in control of this and they have made it easy for tourist. Tickets are free and small groups leave every few minutes. You are welcome to take pictures and after the tour, can also tour other homes and walk the street which is much as it was in the time the Lincolns lived there. Some of the funiture was owned by them, some are replications. It's a thrill.

This is a free attraction. You tour the home of Abraham Lincoln from when he was an attorney in Springfield, IL. The tour is free, but you have to get a ticket. Parking is $2.00 an hour though and is self service. It is neat to walk in the steps of Lincoln. The Tour Guide talks a little about the Lincoln Family. Bottom line - it's free!

You can't come to Springfield without going to the Lincoln homesite. There is no fee to tour the home, but you must have a ticket and they have been known to run out. There is a large parking lot, so you don't have to worry about parking on the street. However, there is a $2.00 an hour parking fee. There is plenty to see and downtown and the Presidential Library are not too far away.

Second time visiting this National park. Excellent film to get you started. Get there early to get you tickets for the house tour, it's worth it. Parking is $2 per hour and there Ar about 6 RV slots although It is in down town Springfield.

This is an amazing slice of history. Be sure to wait to get a good tour guide for the house. Tickets are free so no reason not to go! Wander through the streets and be sure to watch the movies. I had no idea what I didn't know about Lincoln! A must do with the family.

The visit to Lincoln's Home and the walk through the surrounding neighborhood is free, but watch out for parking in the lot. The tour is worth it and the National Park's Service guide make the tour of the Lincoln home interesting. She was well-informed. The visitor's center is also interesting and contains some more Lincoln facts. You need to go into the visitor's center and get a ticket for the tour, but the tour is free. The frustrating part was that we went to park in the lot prior to the tour. You need to pre-pay in the lot at $2/hour. It really frustrated us as we didn't know when we would be able to get a tour or how long we would be there. We just guessed at 2 hours and we were fine, but it was just frustrating. It is worth the trip.

When you arrive at the Lincoln home the parking lot charges two dollars per hour payable at a kiosk. You walk over to the visitor center and you will receive your ticket to tour the home, tours are free. We had to wait a half hour for our tour, but then the other tours seemed to be every five minutes after that. There is plenty to do as there are many homes that are restored with in a couple of blocks to view the historical information on and one other to self tour. We spent about an hour looking at the other homes. The Lincoln at home tour begins with a park ranger giving you the "rules" to tour the home. Once you're inside there are four stops the park rangers talk to you about the rooms and answer questions. They do a great job taking you back to visualize when the Lincoln's lived there.
We visited with kids and got our Passports stamped. The boys, aged 10 and 12, were interested in the tour of the house, and it was just the right length to keep them engaged.

Can't believe entrance is free. Just pay $2 per hour for parking. Tour guide was very good. The home has about 75% original pieces in it. The rest are recreations. Home takes about 25 minutes, but there is a 30 minute movie to watch prior. Might want to take a stroll around the neighborhood too.

My husband and I are both history buffs and this was a treat. A replica of the home LBJ was born in and the cemetery were cool, but the old air force one and the home were the best. I loved seeing the closets of LBJ & Ladybird, plus all the 1960's "hi-tech" gadgets. It was only $3, what a bargain!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Very interesting. The ranch house has been restored to its appearance when LBJ was president and used it as his Texas White House. You hear history and stories on the tour. Admission is $3. Also in the park are the family cemetery, his grandfather's house, and his birth place. It is beautiful country. LBJ had his guests sign their names in concrete on "friendship stones". Some of them are displayed in the area when you leave the ranch house. There is also a film at the Visitor's Center.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This is very unassuming from the road but make the time, stop and see! Wow! I didn't get to see everything this visit so its on my list to stop again next time in the area. You stop at the park station and go inside for a free permit to drive the grounds which are massive! The only cost I encountered was 3 dollars for a 30 min tour of the ranch home for adults. The 4 and 6yr olds with me were free. The park rangers were friendly and informative. This is a working ranch so you see livestock and deer. Bison and a non electric homestead were available to see too. The plane the President traveled on from Austin to the ranch is there because there is a long landing strip in the middle of the property! His cars are on display as well as a lot of memorabilia. History in the form of photos, documents, and video can be seen! Our tour ranger gave great insight into the history of the house and also of LBJ that you may not have known. His family has so much history in the land. The girls enjoyed it, we all did, a must see for me! Too much to list, stop and see for yourself!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Interesting park tour with a tour of the Texas White House. This is definitely worth the $3.00 admission to the house otherwise everything is free.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: I don't know how anyone can give less than 5 stars to this place. It is absolutely a must visit if you are in the area. There is no entrance fee to the park it self. You can visit the ranch originated in late 1800s. The staff there is very friendly and will explain and show you something about life back in the old days. The LBJ ranch tour takes you across the Pedernales river, passing by the boyhood home, family cemetery and LBJ's grandfather's house. Then after you make the loop you reach the hangar where the president's plane is presented. If you want the tour of the Texas White house, it is $3 for adults and free for kids. It takes about 30 min and our park ranger was Patrick. He was very knowledgeable and introduced out to many details about President's and Mrs. Johnson's lives. You get a glimpse of a 60's era since the house was restored to look like it's from the period when LBJ was a president. I am so happy to have visited this place and learned something about history of TX and the US. Would highly recommend it! It's worth your time and money!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We were a little hesitant our children (16, 15, 13, 13, and 8) would not enjoy visiting this park. It is large and we knew it would take the better part of the day. We were afraid they would get bored. We could not have been more wrong. We started at the welcome center. Toured the boyhood home and then walked to the settlements. We then took the drive over to the ranch, cemetery, and Texas Whitehouse. We combined this park with the LBJ state park tour as well. It was a hit. Oh and it was cheap. The only charge was $3 and that only applied to the people over 18 in our party. Our youngest completed an activity book and was " sworn in" as a junior park ranger. She loved it!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: For years I've wanted to visit the Park and heading for Austin from Fredericksburg, just after lunch, and with a few hours to spend, I stopped to see what was available. There is no fee to enter the park, but if you want to tour the Texas White House (aka the former home of President and Mrs. Johnson), it will cost you $3...very reasonable! LBJ's vice presidential jet is on premises - at the hangar next to the gift shop, where you purchase a guided tour (led by a ranger) of the home - and you can even climb the stairs and peer inside. This is still a working ranch and full of historical buildings as well as the family cemetery, where both the Johnsons now reside.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This is a must see stop in the Hill Country. One can't deny that LBJ came to rise during a controversial time in history (Vietnam, racial equality) and you can't get away from the fact that he was a character! This tour takes you through his one room school house, where he loved to learn and was influenced later in life to push for education legislation. The pioneer farm is a working farm, complete with animals and volunteers in period dress, performing period tasks. The ranch is a working ranch. You see family homes, cabins, a show barn with livestock, airplane hangar, cattle herd, and you get to tour his personal residence, the Texas White House.The home has been meticulously restored to look as it did during LBJs presidency. Even though the home was modernized, Lady Bird kept the furnishings appliances, linens, and art work so that the home could go back in time upon their deaths. This self guided tour comes with a perfectly time audio CD to take you through the sights (provided you drive the posted speed limit!). The Texas White House tour is ranger guided and costs an extra $3 per adult. Well worth it. Great for all ages.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Tour of the white house itself was interesting,and a good deal for $2. It was interesting to see some of the furnishings and items they actually used, and to learn that he spent over 500 days of his presidency there. The ranch is still a running ranch with a runway running right through it.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: I really enjoyed this experience. The video in the visitors ceter was an informative start. Next we took the drive around the LBJ property. It was beautiful. along the way, we stopped in for a look at LBJ's school. We finished up with a guided tour of the President's home. Our guide was excellent and the tour was very interesting. All this for $3.00. What a bargain!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We decided to drop in for a tour at Mammoth Cave on our was home from Tennessee. The only tour available was the ‘Mammoth Passage tour.’ The tour was 1 hour and 15 minutes and cost $7 per ticket. If you are into history then I would definitely recommend taking a tour in this cave. I loved hearing about how the cave played a part in the war of 1812. We would like to return and take a few of the more in-depth tours available. Very good experience .

Beautiful park. Very informative area inside plus the tours are inexpensive compared to other caves. We did the discovery tour for $5 a person and walked through a portion of the cave ourselves. Couldn't beat it! We saw the Historic entrance and then walked around some trails near the Green river afterwards. The paths are nicely maintained. We will be back with our kids when they're a little older and able to walk around more without getting tired.

A great experience !!! We chose the Historic Tour (2.5 h), it was history and there were extreme passages in tight places, we walked down the stairs several times, felt very deep underground. Rengers were alert all the time. Lightly illuminated places in the cave added magic and mystery to this trip. CheapTickets $ 14 person

My husband and I just got back from a perfect weekend camping at Mammoth Cave National Park. We were fortunate enough to have good weather, and had a great time. We took the Discovery Tour (only $7!) and primitive camped at the Mammoth Cave Campground (only $20!). Everybody that we encountered was extremely friendly - staff and visitors. And the entire park (even the campground bathrooms) were really well maintained. This was a perfect getaway for us, as it's only an hour and a half drive from Nashville. Will be returning soon and recommending to friends!

We did the "Domes and Dripstones" tour. It was $15.00 and well worth it. Be aware there are around 500 steps, and many narrow and short passageways. They book over 100 people on the tour so there is quite a bit of waiting for slower folks. There's no electricity at the campground and showers cost extra.

We did the self guided $5 tour. It was amazing! Myself and 2 teenage girls headed to Florida for spring break made a spur of the moment decision to stop and see a cave. They loved it! Great National Park!!

I'm not sure how this compares with other caves, but it was quite impressive. We took the $5 self-guided tour and spent about 45 minutes in them, though you could stay longer if you wanted to. There are guided tours in the exact same place as the self-guided tours, so if you want the 1.5 hour history lesson, that is a good option, but with young kid (5 years old), the self-guided option was better for us so we could go at our own pace. There are other guided tours you can pay for that take you into other areas which are restricted from the self-guided tour, and if we had more time or planned in advance (as they were all sold out when we went), it surely would have been interesting to see too.

We went on a Wednesday afternoon & found the tours sold out for the day. After consulting a Ranger, we bought tickets ($15pp) for the 9:30AM "Domes & Dripstones" tour on Thursday October 13, 2016. The description tells you what you'll see, how long the tour is (2 hours), the distance (.75 miles) & how many stairs there are (500). The difficulty is 'moderate'.

This was a great place we took a 2 hr tour was great a lot of stairs not for people with back or knee problems,the park has everything you would want walking trails,horseback riding, canoeing,camping, biking trails,can fish in park ( don't need a License) was Beautiful! It is pet friendly (can't take on tours )but don't worry the hotel has kennel were you can leave them for about $10 and you don't have to be staying at hotel to rent, we did was great we got to take tour though we would miss out do to having our loved dog only thing there is NO wifi or cell phone reception in park that I could get ( have AT&T)

We only did the 5 dollar self guided but it was a good time. The cave is really cold so bring a jacket. I can't wait to go back and do the full spelunking. As the tour for 5 dollars is very quick we did some hiking around the cave and it was awesome.

I took my eight-year-old nephew while visiting and when we got there around 11 AM, all the tours were sold out for the day. We were just killing time, so we decided to take the self-guided tour for $5, I think. It was a perfect little gist of the caves. It's a bit of a hike back up from the caves, but on a really hot day, the temperature change is really nice and almost chilly. The guides are fun to listen to and it was a great time.

We didn't have much time so we did the self guided tour. This is a great tip to do of you do t have much time or have really young children because you do it at your own pace. This tour is only $5, I was disappointed that they didn't offer it free for military... Most national parks do. The Rangers where helpful and answered questions so it was almost like a personalized tour.

Lots to do and not enough time to do it. Beautiful spot with tons of activities. Tours for all ages. Tours a little pricey for a national park paid for with tax dollars but overall well worth the visit.

We went on four tours at Mammoth Cave The park itself is very beautiful and very large thousands of acres.The whole experience was very different and unusual we enjoyed it and learned a lot about Mammoth Cave.There are a few things people should deffinetly be aware of first I wouldn't recommend anybody to bring any children under five years old or anyone with serious health conditions that might not be able to make it through these cave tours there are many many steps up and down rough terrain,many very wet areas wear good hiking boots,There are very tight and low hanging places in the cave.If You are scared of tight dark places don't go there areas that are very large but you sometimes have to go through tight crooked areas to get to them.If You have any breathing issues bring Your inhaler or maybe don't go.Its very cool in the caves 54 degrees which felt good to me but may be cool to You.Bring or wear a jacket the cave is very interesting when You leave the cave You will experience a temperature change and get hot very quickly stay hydrated drink lots of water.also everyone go to the restroom first these tours are kind of long most two hours.Make sure its the kind of tour You want they vary.Also no cell signal in the park and most of the whole area they need more cell towers in the area.Your GPS may not work right ours didn't get a physical map.You will be driving for long periods the rivers in the area are flooded right now when we were there it rained five inches in one night.We missed our last tour and had to cancel theres a three dollar charge for this on each ticket.Have Your vehicle checked out before this trip if You break down then no phone signal is available.The visitors center has wifi but its sketchy and weak.If You are fully prepared then and know what Your getting into then You will enjoy the cave.Pictures are allowed but no flash photography.I would also suggest bringing a cooler for water,drinks snacks,sandwiches etc.they have a water refill area at the visitors center.Remember too there are deer and wild turkey in the area so careful driving and if You go enjoy Your trip we did except for getting misplaced the last day due to faulty GPS get a map.Thank You I hope I could be of some help.I will add photos later.Small children and babies it scared while we were there due to the darkness plus in my opinion it coyuld be dangerous for them and they probably wouldn't remember it anyway so its up to You most will probably cry the ones in our groups did and I felt bad for them because they were scared its dark in caves especially the night tours.The whole area is very pretty though.

What a cool place to explore. There are plenty of trails on the "surface" to explore. I recommend booking tours online in advance. We arrived around 11am and most were sold out already. My friend and I did the 'Domes and Dripstones' tour, which was fun. We also did the self guided tour, which was okay. The self guided tour costs $5 and allows you to wander a very short distance into the main entrance. Guided tours can have well over 100 people, so we did a lot of waiting around. This wasn't too bad because we were in a really cool cave, with lots of areas to look at. 'Domes and Dripstones' had a ton of stairs that lead you down into the cave, but nothing too challenging. I do not recommend wearing flip-flops. Parts of the cave floor were slippery and my sandals didn't have the traction I needed. Also, as you leave the tour you are required to walk over soapy mats. My sandals and feet were gross and sticky afterwards.

We went on 2 separate cave tours. The Historic Tour and the Dome and Dripstone's Tour Each tour lasted about 2 hours and were about $15 per person. They take you from the Visitor Center by bus to the cave openings, They are guided tours by a Park Ranger who has the the answers for everything. It was amazing of how all of the formations are formed over the years and was very memorable. These tours are good for both adults and kids. Beware.. you don't have to be in Super-Shape but It can be strenuous as there are some stairs to climb up and down, plus trails to walk on inside the caves. The Ranger was very patient for visitors who were slow. Someday I would like to go on the Wild Cave Tour which is 6 hours long and 5 miles in length.. now that's when I get into tip top shape. Enjoy Our national Parks!!

We stayed at the campground. I only rated it very good because there are no water or electric hook-ups, but the campground area was immaculate. The area was beautiful and well maintained. Plenty of hiking/bike trails in addition to the caves. Prices for tours was reasonable.

I live in Kentucky and have gotten my National Park Passport stamped in many places in the US, but finally made it to Mammoth Cave. Was so glad we waited because it is the 200th anniversary. This is a beautiful area and has lots to do for all those that love the out doors.

Traveling back from Florida I had the sudden desire to go to Mammoth Cave since our teen-ager had never been. Poor planning on my part made the tours limited for us to experience. The only tour available was the self-guided discovery tour at $5/person this was a great deal and we were able to experience the vastness of this caving system. It truly whetted our appetite to come back and see more! In speaking with one of the park rangers (who, btw, are readily available around almost every corner) she mentioned to check on specialty tours before our next trip. These are tours of the caves that are available on a limited basis annually. My favorite tour is the Frozen Niagra tour and had we planned ahead we may have been able to experience it. Lesson learned for this traveler!

We traveled from Hendersonville, TN were we stayed during our trip. We came here on a whim, as we heard other fellow hotel guests discuss it. It was about 1:30 hours from the hotel. Definitely need reservations for the longer, guided tours. The self guided tour was very cheap, only about $21 for a family of 5. It was short, less than an hour. For someone who had never been to any cave, it was amazing. We also did a short trail. No entrance fees, except for the cave tours. The kids did. Jr. Ranger Program(free) . The staff that processed the books were extremely polite and answered NY questions the kids had. Worth a drive if in the area. Otherwise, definitely need reservations for the tours.

Spent just one day here and wished we had more time to spare. Its very reasonable ticket prices for a national park. For $12 each my huaband and I went on the new cave entrance tour which takes you down very narrow sets of stairs. Having to duck and bend to get through some spots. If your claustrophobic I wouldnt reccomed this tour. We went on a monday and it was packed, i couldn't imagine what the wekends look like. Our ranger told us the best time to come is in the winter, the tour groups are very small then. At the end of the tour is frozen niagara which is truely beautiful. I could've just spent hours photographing it, but alas the rangers move you along. The park does shuttle you by school bus to and from each cave sight.

We were on our way to Kentucky and decided this could be fun. My husband and I loved it as did our 7 and 9 year old. We did the historic tour which is moderate but we thought it was easy. Super cheap prices on the cave tours( $40 for 4 of us) and many trails to go discover on your own. This was the favorite thing we did for my 9 year old and we did Six Flags. Grand Ole Opry, museums and more. Only downfall...we don't live closer.

Both the New Entrance and Historic tours are totally worth the trip. Beautiful and amazing! Definitely try to call and order tickets before you go as it is very busy and tickets go fast the day of. Also, make SURE you are a little early for your tour. We took our youth group and the van broke down on the way; we missed our tour by one minute, and were charged $3/ticket for being "no shows".

Mammoth Cave National Park has clean camping grounds, we chose site 48, close to bathrooms, good for small kids. Staff cleans camp restrooms well, leaving them smelling clean actually. Camp showers are 2$ for a token that gets you 10 minutes. Showers are at camp store a walk ouside the camping area. Bring you flip flops, shower floors are wet and less that tidey at times with bugs and "stuff". Tiny space for changing as you enter shower by the way.. tight space for mom's with small kids. Park rangers are n ice, engaging and sem to monitor the camp area well. The park ranger talks that they sometimes give at dusk did not engage our family much and could be improved on.

Barney was our tourguide of the day and he was great. Funny and he had a lot of knowledge and intereresting stories to tell about the house. Also not too expensive(10 dollars) so if you get the chance, visit this house. It is not a plantation house though, still reasons enough to visit

We did not expect much from a Park Service property with a low admittance of $10 for adults/$5 seniors. We were blown away with the exquisitely furnished home. Our tour guide was knowledgeable and enthusiastic. This is a must see in Natchez!
The grounds are beautiful, great place to have lunch. Really enjoyed the tour of the home, the Park Rangers are very knowledge of the home and families history. Senior tickets are $5.00.

This is still the premier ancient native ruin complex. There is so much to see that it can be challenging. The two big cliff dwelling attractions can only be done with a reservation and ticket ($5) so go there a day early to the visitor center just before the park entrance and get signed up. I would suggest a spring or fall trip as the crowds are a quarter of what they are in the summer months.

Mesa Verde National Park is a must stop if you want to get a deeper understanding of America's indigenous history. Definitely try to book the ranger-guided tours to some of the cliff dwellings so that you can explore them from close and not just see them from distance. They cost only 5$ each and you can buy them up to two days in advance at the tourist office in Cortez,CO or at the park's gate. You cannot purchase them online, you have to show up physically there. Please keep in mind that the tours tend to get sold out very quickly, so it is better if you go the day before to get the tickets.

I'm so glad I changed the route of our roadtrip to get to this place! It's worth it! We did a tour at Cliff Palace! Bought tickets that morning at the Colorado welcome center in Cortez! We were lucky, the moment we walked in a man also stepped in to the building.. he had tickets for the cliff palace on the time we wanted to go, but it was full! He and his wife couldn't make it to get there.. so we bought the tickets after he got his money back from the welcome center! The drive to the cliff palace is nice! Our tour guide was a funny man, who could tell a lot about his place! The tour was much longer than we expected! So worth every 5 dollars! 5 dollars! That's nothing, for everything you get in information and experience! The Cliff Palace was beautiful! I'm so glad we've visited this place! Definitely didn't wanna miss it!

I can't believe they charge for their tours. They have changed their part a bit in that they no longer allow tourist to walk near the ruins without paying for a tour. If you don't pay their $5 charge for each attraction, you can only see the ruins from a distance. Someone needs to rein in the National Park service. A typical family of 4 would pay $20 to enter, and $5 for each tour. If you visit their 3 popular ruins, that means $20 x 3 plus the $20 entrance. They aren't making this affordable for the average working class family. I should not be precluded from walking near the ruins simply because I can't afford the extra fees or failed to get a ticket days in advance.

We went on celebrity cruise to Ketchikan! Took an excursion by seaplane to see misty fjords ! Wow ! What an amazing fjords ! The view by sea plane was amazing and we came by a small boat! What an experience for 340 dollars a person it is an expensive excursion but worth the money spent ! Life time experience! Must do !
$260 is a fair bit to pay for a 90 minute activity but it's worth it here. Taquan is professional, they move everyone along nicely and the whole experience is fabulous.

Booked this excursion on Princess Cruises for $199.95. Excursion lasted 4 1/2 hours and consists of a ride on a very new boat followed by a 1/2 hour float plane ride back to Ketchikan. Saw a few bald eagles on the boat but not much whale activity. Naturalist on the boat ride gave good information, ride was very smooth and flight was excellent.

Very hesitant to take this tour. Get off one boat( cruise ship) just to get on another boat for 4 1/2 hours just sounded crazy but boy was I wrong. The Misty Fjord tour arranged through our cruise line was amazing and more than we expected. The boat was very comfortable, binoculars were provided, free hot chocolate and coffee, Alaskan beers sold for $6, plenty of window seating the day we went, nice size balconies to go out on to take pictures , 3 clean restrooms, lots of wildlife sightings (orca whales, deer, seals and their pups, lots of Eagles), and a free lunch of either vegetarian chili or chowder. The vegetarian chili was delicious and gluten free! Sonja, our tour guide, was awesome and did a great job narrating the tour. The artisan on board was great too. He was a native Alaskan and spoke of his life in a very fun and interesting way. He was selling his work but there was no pressure to buy. There is a small gift shop on board. I am very glad we chose to go on this tour because with the limited time we had in Ketchikan the only way to see this fjord was by this boat or on a float plane. We were lucky too that we had perfect weather.

Ketchikan seaplane offered no extra value to my three family members despite 70 minutes and 220 dollars per person.Less scenic view (just forest) than expected or than Tracy am from cruise vessel next day.

The two attractions at this site are Ford's Mansion where Gen Washington and his staff stayed and a museum that houses some fine Revolutionary War artifacts. Park Rangers offer a guided tour of the mansion that provides a wonderful perspective of its history and helps you relate to our first Commander-in-Chief during his winter encampment. The mansion is well maintained and authentically furnished. There are some very interesting things to see in the museum so take your time and enjoy it. I suggest you sign up for the tour of the mansion first and then use your waiting time to view the video and soak in the museum around your tour time. There is a $4 entry fee, unless you have a National Park pass that covers admission. If you have the time, consider visiting the Morristown Commons and nearby Jockey Hollow where Washington's troops encamped during the winter of 1779-1780. Though not as impressive as the HQ, these additional sites provide interesting historical perspective for the history buffs.
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: We just spent the morning there. The drive up was fascinating with many photo and hiking opportunities. Easy drive, too. No surprises for the squeamish. We made it only to the Paradise Visitors Center with roads beyond that still closed for the winter(Ranger says maybe 5/26/17). But that's as high as you get, 5400 ft, from what I'm told. Breathtaking views up and down. Great way to spend a morning. Seniors: Advise the Ranger at the Entrance. 62+ gets a huge discount and a Lifetime Pass..

We were staying in Tacoma for and decided to visit Mt Rainier. about an hour drive to the park entrance but the traffic backed up to enter the Park on the holiday weekend exceeded 5 miles and took an hour to wade through. Once in the park still busy but there was parking to be found and beautiful vistas. Not much to do at the visitors center a movie and a snack bar wit the usual high price average quality fare. In summer there is some snow at the Visitors Center so bring your sliding sleds for the snow along with gloves, a spare pair of shoes socks, pants, a towel, sunscreen and water.about 25 mins to the visitors center from the entrance. $25 national park entrance fee good for 7 days.

We went here because our flight didn't depart u til 10:30pm. I thought it would be a good way to spend the day, and the area did not disappoint. He scenery was breathtaking and the drive was gorgeous. Passing through the small, moi rain towns was an experience all of its own.

Only $5 to see with senior discount. It is everything you could imagine and more. Stop in the visitor’s center book store to your right as you enter to get the lay of the land. We had to back track because we were confused about where the museum was located. Plan for about an hour.

Mount Rushmore National Memoral is free to visit but $10 for annual parking pass. This is a must see for everyone coming through Black Hills area. We went around sunset, after going thru gift shop & walking Presidential Trail it was almost time to sit and enjoy the evening illumination ceremony. The gift shop is very nice and has many reasonable priced souvenirs.

Came to South Dakota to visit here, Custer State Park, and Badlands. Figure 2-3 hours if you see the film and museum, walk the trails, and take in the sights. If you are 62 and up parking is only $5. Getting in to the Memorial is free. Museum and movie are worth seeing for good information. My recommendation for the Presidential Trail is to go up on the left side and come down the right as you face the Presidents, much easier walk. The restaurant complex is excellent. Unlike some National Park food courts this one is priced competitively and the choices can't be beat. Would recommend eating here if you get the chance.
We were really happy that we finally went inside this memorial. Great pricing at $10.00 per car and that is good for a year! Walking trail goes back, for closer views

We stopped here while vacationing. I haven't been here in about 20 years. It was a lot closer than I remembered. And I was able to get some great pictures. It's a great piece of history that everyone should experience at least once. We came back another night for the light ceremony, which is also a must see. And it was free to get back in. Your parking pass is good for a year! Worth the $10. There is an exhibit in the building below the main landing and a trail you can walk.

you pay $10 to park and the pass is good for a year so you don't have to do everything at one visit. We went back several times and loved each time. If you love nature, you will love the view and the animals. The eateries are expensive so stay clear. We brought our own drinks in (I suggest water)

After paying the $10.00 for parking we were able to get a close parking spot in the parking ramp. You can take an elevator or take the stairs up to the level you need. Soooo many people. Hard to get around without getting in someones way. Gift shop had a good selection of items.

16 years to do this impressive work of art, imposing and beautiful. there is in the park a theater with the history of this monument. Restaurant, auditorium and ice cream shop. All you have to pay is $ 10 per car. Not good cel coverage in the area
Must see if in the area! Be prepared to pay $10 just to Park. They also don't accept the National park annual pass. Must see though!

It was super fun despite being really cloudy. It did kind of clear for periods of time so you could make out the men. I'd pay attention to weather and if it looks like there will be breaks in a cloudy day- go during that time! The "walk" is super short, just a bunch of stairs. $10 parking, good for a week!

Definitely a must see! The park is free to visit but parking pass cost $10 however, the pass is good for the year! There are a few trails, the artist work shop and the museum all on site. Don't forget to drive beyond and look for the profile of GW.

This is a must see when travelling through the area. It is a bit crowded, but worth it. It does cost $11 for parking. You can make the trip as long or as short as you would like depending on your interest.

We arrived at 8am, paid the $10 parking fee, and had a very enjoyable walk around the Presidential Trail, which in my opinion is the best thing on offer here. At that hour, it is a peaceful and beautiful experience with impressive views of the monument.
This was a highlight of my first week of the vacation - such an impressive sight. There's not much to it - pay your $10 for parking - walk down the pathway and enjoy fabulous views of the monument.

We went to Mount Rushmore right away in the morning. It is $10 to park. That pass is good for the entire calendar year. We took the trail, watched the movie, and saw everything we could. We then returned about 8:15 for the night show. We didn't have to pay again. There is a talk by a ranger, a movie, and a patriotic song while they light up the monument. The most moving part for me was when they called all the veterans or active military to the stage. I highly recommend seeing it in the day and night.

We took my parents on there first road trip in many years. When u first lay eyes on the monument the car is filled with ooos and ahhs.. parking was $5 and u get the full adventure and all the information u can take in. You must walk the path and get right under the faces,the 0.2 walk is handicap accessible. and go into the museum and see how these men built this beautiful sculpture, and learn the true story behind it all!!
Very inspiring. $10 parking was very fair. Pretty busy but I'm sure it varies based on time of day. We came at lunchtime.

This monument is an absolute must see when your visiting the Black Hills. The presidential trail gets you an up close look at this marvel. And for the price of $10 per car load ( which is good for a year) it would be silly to not stop and take this in!!

We visited in the evening and went to the lighting ceremony. We had 2 hours to walk the Presidential Trail and visit the exhibits in the visitors center before the program. Entrance is free and parking is $10, $5 if you are 62 or older, and free if you are a Veteran. I enjoyed the program before this lighting ceremony with the flag lowering ceremony which included all the Veterans in the audience. It was very patriotic, and a good reminder of what these four Presidents did to help shape our Country.

When you get to Mount Rushmore, admission is free, but there is a $10 fee for parking. Parking is easy. At the entrance to the park, you will walk through a promenade of all of the state flags. There is a gift shop and food court located nearby. The food court has a variety of food and there are tables outside with umbrellas for shade and shelter. Eventually you reach the large deck to view the amazing sculpture. There is a Presidential Trail that is easy to walk and you can get a closer view of the sculpture. There were lots of people, but it never felt too crowded for me. Definitely spend some time in the Visitor Center down by the amphitheatre. It is well done and the movie was very informative about the carvings. Best part about Mount Rushmore is that I was proposed to, so I will always have fond memories of this place.

This is my first time visiting Mount Rushmore and it was on my bucket list of places to visit. Let me tell you it just beautiful and interesting the history on Mount Rushmore. Great Place to visit for about two hours. This National Park only charge for parking about $10, so I highly recommend visiting this amazing National monument.
It was so amazing to see such an aawesome and incredable monument structure, that was man-made! Well worrth the drive! However, plan on paying a $10 parking fee!

Warning get there early morning morning or late night.. car Line is very very long if u go at high peak .. it may take you 45 minutes wait .. it's not free parking understandably for the national parks are underfunded and parking is owned by another company. It's ten dollars for the whole year .. but must be same vehicle only. Not transferable.. but the Mt Rushmore is a must see ..

Auto entry fee was $10, they do not accept a senior pass if you have one. This is a must see, lots of exhibits to tell you all about the memorial. You'll love it. If you can arrive via Iron Mountain road, come from the south to north on that road through Custer State Park for a grand entrance.
Every American should see. Take your time. Audio tour is worth the $5. Walk is not bad. Great day. Took motorcycle.

Our schedule was so that we could only visit in the evening. Parking was very close no over crowding. The only downside it that they do not accept the interagency national park pass because you pay $10 for parking not admission to the park. On a summer trip filled with national parks you would think they would at least offer a discount to national park pass holders.

We went to the 9:30 pm light up reveal. It was beautiful, however it pales to seeing it in the daylight. During the day you get to see all the details in the rock. You can see all the boulders that have fallen in order to make such a magical monument. The crowd all leaves at once, usually 15 minutes after the reveal, causing traffic to back up. For us daytime was better, but since the admission is only $10, try both!

We made a stop to Mount Rushmore on our way to the Grand Canyon and really enjoyed it. Getting to the memorial was very easy. The parking structure is built into the mountain and it's a short walk to the memorial. Parking only cost $10 for a 12 month pass and the view was great from all angles. I would recommend stopping here to check it out. There's local stuff to do nearby if you plan to spend a couple days in the area.

Yes, it's worth it. Even the three skeptics with me agreed at the end that they were glad they spent the $5. Bring your own ear phones or just hold device up to your ears. You can progress through the stops at your pace.
We enjoyed our visit here. Great museum about the construction of Rushmore. Perfect photo location. Parking is $10 but it says annual pass so you can return that calendar year.

Great place to stop only 10 dollar charge to park amd that is good for the rest of the year!! Definitely go on the presidential trail because it gives you a closer view of the faces. Very interesting place. Of course you have to try the ice cream they sell there!!

Mount Rushmore is worth seeing, and if you travel all this way, invest some time at the memorial. Your $10 parking pass is good for at least a week, and there is no other admission charge. So it may make sense to visit on 2 separate days as we did--one night for the lighting ceremony and an hour or two one day to hike the Presidential Trail and visit the museum.) We really enjoyed hiking the Presidential Trail and learning more about the great effort it took to carve the memorial. The ranger talk at the lighting ceremony is a little long and a bit hokey, but overall it is a wonderful immersion in Americana.
I really thought we would get much closer to the monument. After the parking ($10) and the walk to the viewing site it was sort of anti-climactic.
A must see sight. For $10, you get a yearly pass. We visit on a Thursday evening, so there wasn't many people and view was absolutely beautiful!
What an awesome sight. You can actually see it from all around the Keystone area, but it is totally worth the $10 to get up close.
Processional staff well maintained reasonable rate to get in of $10. Show was okay as well but not as cool as we thought it would be.
$10 parking for vehicles and RV's

Everyone should go see this at least once. It's amazing. Pics in books and on tv doesn't capture the magnificence of this place. You'll be in awe of just how huge and great it looks in person. The museum is great also, there's also a 13 minute film you can watch that touches on how it was built. No admission fees but you do have to pay for parking which is $10 or $5 for seniors.

You can't be in the area and not stop here if you've never been. The 10% inclines leading to the site were no fun in the RV and all the vehicles behind me. The $10.00 in parking is a bit of a pain, but it is worth it. The Presidential trail is a fun walk with the children and the gift shop is a decent size.

Mount Rushmore is a must see if you are traveling through South Dakota or through the eastern side of Wyoming. The area of the black hills is beautiful, and Mount Rushmore itself is remarkable. As you enter, you are greeted with all 50 state flags, as well as a gift shop and a small cafe. The monument itself is astounding, and has a great view upon entrance. There is a $10 parking fee, however it can be used repeatedly for a year. Once you view the monument from the entrance, head down to the visitors center for some great facts about construction, and each of the presidents featured. Take the presidential trail (short, less than a mile) around and below the monument. You will get some amazing picture opportunities. All in all, a great reminder of American history and the values our country was founded on.

I'm sure you don't need a Tripadvisor review to tell you to come see this place. If you are in the area, you are going to see Mt. Rushmore. The question is HOW are you going to see Mt. Rushmore. My in-laws saw it from the road. There are places to pull off, and you could technically do that. I would like to suggest however that the "memorial" well worth the $11 parking fee. Museums, movies, displays, etc. are all well done and very informative. Also the loop trail up to the bottom of the monument was pretty cool. I would recommend taking the walk.

The anticipation of seeing this attraction was far greater than the visit itself. This is a Natkonal Mmemorial, not a National Park. The entrance fee is free, but the mandatory parking fee is $11. Once inside the memorial there are several restaurants and cafes and one large gift shop. Further into the memorial is the main building housing a small museum and theater describing the carving of Mt. Rushmore.
Definitely a must see. We did the presidential trail. We ate onsite and was a bit $$, but can get to go cups and refills to last the entire day.
Evening ceremony is a must to see. Great parking deal. One time payment with yearly unlimited visits

This was a nice attraction. Free, but the $11 parking fee makes it less so. I think that American tourists will get more out of this than foreign visitors. A great landmark for Americans. The constant drone of planes and helicopters does distract from the beauty of the natural surroundings. Take the walk around for more close up views, this part is a lot of stairs, so not for mobility challenged visitors.

My kids and I went for the lighting ceremony but were instead greeted by rain and lightning. We were told while paying the $11 entrance fee that they would still do the lighting ceremony if there was no hail. The rain did die down and the lightning actually made it a very unique experience. Unfortunately they only turned the lights on but with no official ceremony. The faces were tough to see in the rain but it was still a great experience.

3rd time and I still get chills seeing it. This time was just before Sturgis and it was really crowded. I wouldn't recommend going during the motorcycle rally. $11 for parking and there was a small wait.
Went day and night. The night time showing is just not that good, you can't see much detail, and can't do the presidential trail. Go during the day. Parking only $11 and is an annual pass.
Fantastic view of a national treasure! All the facilities and staff were outstanding! No admission fee but parking is $11.00. Definitely recommend this attraction!

Mount Rushmore is a giant carving and the beauty is you can save $11 for parking the car, as there are two places to get great pictures without stopping and going into the establishment. The artistry was impressive but not my favorite site.

You walk away with a sense of pride! This was worth the trip. Only $11 to park and make sure and come back for the lighting of Mt. Rushmore and the changing of the colors. My family enjoyed this experience tremendously!

Driving on the main road you can see the faces on the mountain, but it didn't do justice to the true majesty of the place. You have to go in and see them up close, walk the Presidential trail, watch the movie in the museum and get personal with this place. There were a lot of people there when we visited, but it is so grand and awe inspiring that you hardly notice the other people. Only disappointment is that they do not accept my annual national parks pass, so had to pay the 11 dollar entry fee, but it is absolutely worth it.

While it photographs well, you must see it in person to truly experience it and appreciate it. There is a $11 fee to park. Pay it and enjoy the site. There are several nice patios and the amphitheater as areas to sit and enjoy the view. If you are able, take the Presidential Trail for different views. It has a lot of steps and lots of places to stop for a rest. Glad we did this and also went to the Sculptor's Studio. This has steps also but has the models they worked from and it had a fun ranger talk. Go clockwise on Presidential Trail and steps are easier and you will be at Sculptor's studio near the end.

I haven't been to Mt. Rushmore in about 30 years and we took our kids for the first time. To say that it was amazing would be an understatement. The museum is visible from the road (great for people on a budget or just quickly passing by) and so makes a huge first impression. Our oldest son (7) could hardly keep it together as we pulled into the parking garage b/c he could clearly see the monument. Once into the park, the gorgeous entry and flags set us up for an amazing and special visit. The park is meticulously maintained and the staff is wonderful. There is so much room to move about and explore. The audio tour is good, but not worth the $5 if you're there with young children who won't let you listen to it! The information posted around the site is more than sufficient and gives great, but not overwhelming, detail. Definitely plan to spend a couple of hours enjoying all that this location has to offer.

Not having been to Mt. Rushmore since I was a little girl, this trip was much more memorable. They have opened up a beautiful walking path under the Memorial that allows you to get some amazing views! The entrance is beautiful, with flags from all 50 states. If you are going to do the walk, I would suggest bringing water with you since the water fountain is near the end of the trail. It was quite warm the day that we went and water would have been good. The views from the trail, both of the Memorial and of the countryside are spectacular! We drove back from the Memorial through The Needles which is also a beautiful drive! The park itself is free but parking costs $11 per car.

The views are worth the trip. It's a free site but parking costs $11.00. Still, it's worth it. The viewing areas are spacious so it stays comfortable despite the crowds. SEEING THE OATH OF CITIZENSHIP (for newly naturalized citizens) A REAL SURPRISE.

I went here for 2016 4th of July holiday weekend, very busy but it was not difficult to get in and get a parking spot. I paid $20 to get in but the permit is good until September 2016 in case I come back this year. The park was busy but not overwhelm.

Absolutely wonderful! It costs a mere $11.00 for an annual entry pass for a priceless experience! The trail isn't too strenuous and it is easy to capture nice pictures. The night program is poignant and well worth the second visit. The gift shop is also affordable. So very glad to have had the chance to see it!

I have to teen daughters they both learned new things about Rushmore they enjoyed the trip as I did my wife and I. Great price to get in also only $11 to park and the parking permit is good for the remainder of the year I believe at least does stayed it expired end of December 2016

Worth the eleven dollars to get in. There are views from the road but going to the monument itself, even though it can be very crowded, gets you much closer to Mt. Rushmore and has a hiking trail up toward it

The mountain was cool, and the sculpture is iconic and way more impressive in real life than the photos can ever capture... but the $11 parking fee was uncool. Tourist circus. The "lighting ceremony" was dumb. A monologue by the ranger then a Discovery Channel movie. It was a decent movie but I can watch that at home. Then the lights came on. Not much of a ceremony.
No entrance fee but $11 for parking. Go early-by 8:15 to get a seat. There is a gift shop and ice cream shop. Program starts at 9:00. Over by 9:30.
This is a must see location. Incredible simply incredible - embracing our history!! Price was $11 (year long pass). Videos of the process - trails - inspirational.

Enjoyed the visit to the Memorial. It is very easy to park your vehicle. There is walking up and down steps in the Memorial if you choose to see monument up close. The gift shop was selling some great souvenirs outside the gift shop in a tent for $5.00. Nice items for good prices. The Memorial is an amazing work of art.

Monument was free, we paid $11 for parking which was adequate and expected. Awesome national monument. Staff was helpful and courteous. My son earned his junior ranger badge, we went on the presidential trail, and enjoyed this historical place.

Mount Rushmore is as amazing as they say. You come around the corner and boom you see it. It has a visitors center, theater, gift shop, book store, and a very nice trail that gives you a better look. You won't be disappointed for stopping here. And it's $10 or $11 parking and is good for the rest of the year.

Lots of upgrades to this national park since I visited as a young kid. Had my family with me, including two boys ages 5 and 10. Waited in a long line for the audio tour "wands" and was thrilled that my kids really enjoyed listening to it! ($15 for a family of 4). I'd totally recommend the presidential trail. I'm not physically fit, and it was an easy walk with tons of places to stop and rest (and listen to the audio tour). Be sure to bring a water bottle with you, as there is no water along the trail. The very end of the trail includes some long stairways back to the top. I found those a bit tiresome but still worth it. If you have a stroller or a wheelchair the first half of the trail is accessible, but not the second half past the memorial.
