If you want a closeup view of the memorial but don't want to do the stairs, I'd recommend the first half of this trail before turning around. Overall a successful visit that was extra enjoyable because of the natural beauty of the trail and added value of the audio tour.

Mount Rushmore is totally awesome. We went at night to watch the lighting ceremony and it was beautiful. We went back in the morning and the sky was so blue it made it look all the more lovely. It is free to view but parking is $11.00. Absolutely worth every penny.

I've been to Mount Rushmore four other times and for some reason I enjoyed it even more this time. Parking is $11.00 but otherwise admission is free. There is a visitor center, a shop (of course), an informative sculpture exhibit, a really neat outdoor flag exhibit of all the United States and a walking trail that offers different views of the mountain. It can be a quick visit or you can really take your time and explore the exhibits and learn the history about the sculptor and making of Mount Rushmore.

A great park! If you have not seen them, you must go. The entrance fee is low at 11.00 dollars a car and worth much more. If you go do not miss the profile stop on the way out, about a quarter mile from the exit when you leave.

$11 to park, entry to the park is free. Once in, the approach to the landmark has multiple good vantage points for pictures. There is an amphitheater with lots of room to view the nightly lighting ceremony.

Changed our vacation plans this year to ditch theme parks and visit national parks instead. So this was a must. We arrived before 7am and had the park to ourselves. Just a few people there hiking the trail. Tour busses arrive at 9ish, and the crowds surged at that point. We got all our hiking and pictures taken early, then had time to enjoy to museum and visitors center. FYI - you can sign up to purchase a state flag that hangs on the plaza, probably the coolest momento you could get from a NP. Covered parking is $11, but there is free parking if you are willing to walk. Trail not as strenuous as it sounds, go clockwise and most of the stairs go down. Could not believe how close to the monument you can get. A must see for every family.

I've been waiting to see Mount Rushmore for a long time and finally got the chance on a recent vacation to South Dakota. What an absolutely amazing and awesome sight! I highly recommend taking the Presidential Trail around to the artist's studio. It's a nice little walk with different angles of the Memorial. Although it's not a strenuous hike, there are several stairs. The gift shop is very nice and has friendly staff. We also ate at the cafe and had the driest burger I've ever had and spent $12 on it, so I'm not sure I'd recommend the cafe. But everything else was fantastic. May is also a perfect time to go. Great weather and less crowds!

We had such a good time walking around learning about the monuments. The rangers were great, able to answer any question thrown at them. It was fairly cheap, $11 for an annual parking pass. Don't take the dogs, they'll have to stay in the car and it's pretty warm.

Not the best for parks and scenic beauty and we didn't realize that April is low season. So parts were closed and under repair. But still pretty cool. Don't stop on the road and take a pic and move on. Pay the $11 and park and walk the loop. It was a beautiful day and they call the walk strenuous. It's not. Just a lot of stairs and a few uneven surfaces.

This place is amazing but a heads up. It gets boring very quickly there is only so much you can look at simila e to the grand canyon but a must see. There is a lot of other activities in the area you could spend a whole day in that area. Hotels are cheap and there are local camp grounds. Beware even in April it was in low 20's in the am so dress warm. Another tip the park opens at 5 am but they don't operate the gate to charge until 730 so it's free until then. The park itself is free but normally $11 to park vehicle. Also sunset or sunrise is fantastic as well.

I was rather disappointed by the price and limited access, I understand it's a national monument but you can get almost the same view just driving up to the mountain. If you want to park they charge something like 17$ US, and you can walk in and view the carving from quite a distance away on one of many platforms or trails but you really cannot get within a football field of the rocks so make sure to bring a zoom lens. Their are daily presentations in a huge beautiful outdoor auditorium that was recently built/remodelled and plenty of write ups about the history behind the place and it is quite the site to see and verify the scope and scale behind the project that you may have only viewed in pictures and programs.
Free entry, but $11 parking charge. Popular, but accessible attraction. Definitely worth completing the presidents trail to get a closer view.

To be honest I wasn't that bothered about visiting the monument. We had seen it from a distance on Iron Mountain Road and having bought an annual NPS pass I resented paying the $11 to park the car. However, my wife really wanted to go so how could I refuse. It was an excellent experience, I am glad we went and they do very good vanilla lattes in the cafe. Early morning seems a good time to go for photos, as the sun comes round Washington casts a bit of a shadow over this fellow presidents.

This beauty can't be missed. Autos can enter into the park for $11 and that is good for the rest of the year. They have a nice gift shop and I don't think the prices are too bad. Their cafe is very good and also reasonable in price considering your in a national park.

I have wanted to come here for years. I finally get the chance. I didnt mind the $11 parking fee. But it would have been nice for them to let you know that on the day we visited, 10/5 that there was no visabilty. Walking the president's trail, you could make out washington's nose and lips when you are standing under it. It didn't show up in pictures but I saw it.

I wouldn't drive 500 miles to see it or anything like that but if you're in the area check it out. The road from Rapid City is excellent and the drive only takes about 25 minutes. I thought $11 for parking was a little steep. There's a pull over place where you can view it for free before you get to the entrance but the view is a little better from the park itself. I took 16 W to 385 instead of going back to Rapid City. That will took me through Deadwood which is a pretty cool town.

Driving through the Black Hills was very enjoyable. Beautiful and varied scenery. When we reached the Mount Rushmore entrance, they wanted $11 at the gate, supposedly for parking. The sculpture was visible from the road. Definitely not impressive enough to pay for a closer look.
Went in the afternoon, liked looking at the exhibits and reading about it. Friendly staff at the gift shop! Didn't mind paying the parking lot fee of $11, well worth it!

We chose to go in the evening for the lighting ceremony, which was at 8:00 and lasted about 45 minutes or so. Go 15-30 minutes early to pay ($11 per car- lasts until the end of the year), find parking, and walk to the memorial. Once you get to the viewing terrace you can either stand and watch or you can go down the stairs to find a seat at the amphitheater. There are elevators if you need one.
How can you pass it up, it's a national monument. It's $11 to enter and you can hike and stay all day. The ice cream shop is a good stopping point, especially in the summer! :)
Hey, come on now...it's Mt Rushmore! Go see it, it's worth every minute. There is an $11 parking fee, but no entry fee. Many displays also.

Fabulous to see this up close and in person. I would recommend you go early. We arrived at 8am and there we plenty of parking spaces but when we left at 9.30 it was MUCH busier. Parking is $11 per car. Take a walk around the President's Trail for a different perspective but do it clockwise as it felt like there are less steps to go up that way! The displays underneath the grand view terrace are worth checking out as they give you a real idea of the struggle the workers faced!

We took our 3 kids who normally don't like educational stuff but they enjoyed the memorial too. Only cost $11 per car. Went in morning The Memorial was very cool and the walk around base was nicely laid out to give you information on all 4 presidents and very clean. Went back that night for lighting ceremony which made us proud to be a American and they ask for all military past and present to come on stage to honor them! They even had them say their name and branch of military they severed. Very classy thing to do.

Finally took the kids to see "The Men in the Mountain". Cost 11$ for parking, no other fees. The Presidential Trail (.5 mile loop) closer to the faces is a must. It was crowded at the monument but well managed. We found a Hawaii licence plate in the parking lot which made the kid's day :)
Very clean. Not too crowded. Great drive up. Saw lots of mountain goats. Pay once for parking then can go back throughout the year for free
Clean park, courteous staff, amazing place! Why wouldn't you go? We stayed for the night lighting ceremony...very moving. Get there an hour early for parking...$11.

Mt Rushmore is a must see for every American. But beware I had first visited this monument back in the early 2003 and found that I had to pay for parking. The site was free. It was to help pay for the new parking area. Here it is 12 years later and we are still paying for this parking lot at 11 dollars a shot. It was hard for me to even get 2 hours out of this site it could have been worse most airport charge more for hourly parking. For those who don't mind paying go early in the morning for better picture.

I have waited a long time to see this. The walking paths were relaxing and I enjoyed the history of the place. It cost $11 to get in and we parked in the parking garage. Outside the had a pet walk but pets are not allowed into the memorial. We spent about an hour here and so it was easy to also go to Crazy Horse which wasn't far away.

This is a great place to visit. We all loved it. It is an amazing place to see. It's very clean plenty of viewing areas and easy access. It's approx $11 to park. They have a restaurant on site has well as an ice cream shop, but be prepared to shell out some bucks for them both. But both are great. We ate outside on the terrace and had chipmunks running all around us. Overall this was a great family experience.
This was a great visit to understand the full creation of the memorial. The waiting line at the gate was too long and the fee ($11) per car go to the end of the year to me is dumb.

We visited on a weekday morning and there was a bit of traffic going into the park area -- to be expected during tourist season. It was $14 to enter, but the parking pass lasts all year. We walked up to the presidential trail, and the view was good but a bit anticlimactic. Still an interesting visit, though!

It is one of those things that you have to do while in South Dakota. Admission to the monument is free, but parking is pretty expensive ($18). The monument is as impressive as you would imagine. Half of the presidential trail was closed for maintenance while we were there, but when you do the trail, remember that it has 260+ steps! It is worth it, but wear your comfy shoes instead of your stylish heels. The museum in the bottom of the viewing veranda is very interesting, as is the artist's studio. Listening to the interviews with the Rushmore workers was my favorite part. The gift shops are as you would expect.

A must for any American... I've been here several times as a child and it still was fascinating to me as an adult. Our 9 year old son loved it. The memorial is free to get in, but parking is $11...not too bad. We didn't stay for the lighting ceremony, but I hear it's beautiful.

We saw the monument at night and during the day. Each visit was exceptional. We were not aware of the nightly lighting ceremony and, unfortunately arrived too late to see it. If you go (and I would definitely recommend going), plan to be there about 7:45 pm to park and find a seat in the outdoor theater. The monument entrance fee is $11.00 and good for multiple visits. We returned the following morning to see the monument during the day. It's one of those 'you have to see it to believe it' experiences. Their gift shops area is very nice. Loved my time at this attraction!

Enjoyed our day at the monument. It was relaxig and educational. It was a beautiful day, perfect for lots of pictures. Paying ten bucks for parking for such a short time was a little discouraging, but other than that we enjoyed it.

Mount Rushmore is a must see. We will probably not go back unless they add something or change it. My 6 year old was absolutely amazed by it which was great to see. It was 11 dollars for parking and you can walk up somewhat closer to the monument but there really isn't much in the park itself down stairs there is a little museum which had quite a bit of information and was interesting very large gift shop I think there was a ice cream shop also. There is parking across the street from it for free where u can see it just as well as in the park. It was nice to see but not as impressive as I thought it would be

I happened to be in the area for work and thought I would stop to see this national monument. It was pretty spectacular. My one draw back was that it was $11 to get into the park. I was there for 15 minutes. If I could have spent the whole day there it may have been worth the fee. Otherwise I doubt I'll ever return.

We extended our road trip east in order to visit Mount Rushmore. I've wanted to come here since forEVER, and my seriously high expectations were not damaged in any way. It is exceptional. Loved the drive there, was so damn excited as we exited every bend in anticipation of a first glimpse. The whole place sums up a true iconic American experience for me - a piece of extraordinary architecture, craft and guile, in a stunning 'great outdoors' setting. Will live with me forever and I hope I can afford to return one day. The parking fee of $11 is of course totally worth it, and the easy trails allow you to get a lot closer than I would have expected, with great photo opportunities. Bring binoculars as well to zoom right into these 4 famous faces.

We stayed in Rapid City & this was a nice, easy drive from there. I let myself have no expectations as to not be disappointed & it turned out that I had a really great experience. It was a gorgeous day that added to the beautiful surroundings. I loved walking down the Avenue of Flags with all the state flags & seeing the mountain. We took the Presidential Trail that goes to the base of the mountain. Visited the Sculptor's Studio & museum. It's $11 a car to park & good for all year. There is no admission other than parking. We went back a few days later for the evening program & lighting of the monument. Very patriotic. If, for some reason, you don't want to pay or aren't interested in anything else, you can see the mountain from the road. There is even a pull off to read about the sculptor & take pictures. I didn't eat at the cafe, but I did check it out though because the cafe & Mount Rushmore is in Hitchcock's movie "North by Northwest" that I watched just before visiting. My husband & I thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Mount Rushmore.

We visited Mount Rushmore and thought it was amazing! We arrived late afternoon and decided to stay for the night show where they light it up. Given I am from Australia I found it very interesting to learn about each of the presidents as well some information about America history that I did not know. I highly enjoyed the visit and it was worth the $11 we paid for parking!

Don't know what I imagined, but It more than buried ALL of my expectations! I, of course, thought I knew what it looked like, but I was just blown away by the setting that it's in, the enormity of it, and the beautiful job they've done with the park! Be sure to walk along the Presidents' Trail. There are many steps, but it's so worth the effort to see all the different vantage points of the mountain carving. Along the walk, there are spots where you are only seeing each particular president, and the views are just amazing! Be sure to watch the movie about the making of it, too...so interesting! Yeah, the parking isn't free, but for $11 a carload, it's a bargain to see this amazing and beautiful piece of history!

You can see the carved heads from the pull in on the Highway so unless you really want to see it through a basic telescope or walk through some distantly see it, I would save the eleven dollars entry and do something more enjoyable.

I was somewhat disappointed. I had bought a National Park Pass for my trip, my goal was to go to as many National Parks as possible, well since this is a Memorial I did not have to use my pass to get in, US memorials are free BUT I had to pay someone to PARK! I felt a little cheated from the beginning. The memorial itself was less impressive than what I remembered as a child. Was in and out in an hour tops.

Mount Rushmore was better than I expected. There is a hefty parking fee ($11.00) however it is good until the end of whatever year you visit the park. So you can visit at different times of the day. Go one day and hike the presidents trail and then return another day to see the lighting ceremony. The president's trail given you many photo opportunities that you can't get from the main plaza. The rangers on site are very informative about the monument. It is worth a trip to see, you won't be dissapointed.
It's cooler, less crowded, and more patriotically inspiring. Parking access is great, and the $11 didn't seem bad. The gift shops are still open afterwards.

So surreal to stand in front of it! We walked around the exhibit area and stepped into 1 of 2 videos about Mt. Rushmore. We came in the evening so it was sort of hard to get a good picture of the monument until the sun lowers, but the evening ceremony to light the monument was great! Would go back! (By the way, the $11 parking fee is good for a year.)

Was really cool to see. It was $11 per car load to see. They had elevators and easy access. It was very clean. They had a couple of Info/shop centers. A lot of people had the same idea we did though. :) Clean restrooms and food available.

Take your pictures from the highway pull over and save the $11 parking fee. They don't' t accept NP Senior Passes. Has a nice gift shop with tourist stuff and a video presentation on how it was made, but if you have seen the History Channel documentary as we had, we skipped that. After 20 minutes of picture and a walk through the gift shop we left. Most disappointing NM we visited in our 5250 mile West Road trip.

What a fabulous place to bring your children! Only 2 complaints: 1) they say the park is free but charge a mandatory $11 parking fee. Just tell people it costs $11. 2) many of the souvenirs at this NATIONAL monument are made in China. I told the management that I refused to buy anything at a national treasure that was made elsewhere!

Loved Mt. Rushmore! Had to pay $11 to park at an otherwise free national site. No military discount here just plenty of attitude by the parking fee collector. Of all places you would think military personnel would not have to pay to get in. No free parking anywhere.

We decided to take a easy roadtrip up from Denver to visit Mt. Rushmore and Devils Tower. I was surprised how beautiful this area of South Dakota is. Mt.Rushmore is in a beautiful setting of trees and rock formations. Parking was easy in a parking garage with a easy walk to the entrance. It was $10 entrance fee per car. As you walk in the view of the faces is framed by a walkway edged with all the U. S. flags. The paved presidential trail was easy, even for an out-of-shape middle-age mom. There were alot of stairs at the end so if you want to skip them you can walk the first half of the trail and turn back and still see all the best stuff. We stopped for lunch in the cafe afterward. It was mostly hamburgers and hot dogs with a few other offerings. I had stew that was pretty good. Great gift shop too! Overall, this was definitely worth the visit!

The $11 fee to get in serves as your season pass. The history and tradition that comes with Mt Rushmore is simply amazing. We visited a few times and returned again at night for the lighting ceremony. It was a nice ceremony that shows the history of the area and a terrific way to honor those who serve past or present in the military. It sure is a reminder of how history repeats itself and a great US history lesson for our kids. It is an amazing place. Be sure to walk the presidential trail for up close views and photos.

My wife and I went to Mt. Rushmore and it blew us away. Is it smaller than we expected? Yes, but over all this is a must see place. The accomplishment of carving the mountain is mind blowing. The detail of the faces will never be forgotten. We would also recommend doing the audio tour in order to answer those questions that everyone has. It is $5 for the tour but we feel it was worth it. The staff was all very nice and accommodating.

Does not accept the national parks interagency pass, so $11 to park. Very rude staff -- pushy, threatening, and hostile. I will never return until they accept the national parks interagency pass, and I doubt I'll buy another interagency pass after my experience here.

This is a place everyone should see if they can. The annual national park passes don't work here. Be prepared to pay $11, for parking. There is a museum and bookstore with interesting information about the creation of this monument. I don't usually watch the movie but would recommend this one because of the background it provides. It is only 15 minutes long. An hour was enough time for us to take photos, watch the movie, and browse the stores.

$11 to park. Parking pass is good for all year. We went in the morning. It was raining and foggy but we looked at the exhibits until the fog lifted. We went back at night to see the lighting ceremony. It is amazing. Go back at night if you can.

$11 to park and the pass is good all year! Doesn't except National Park Pass, FYI. What an AMZING place! Learned a few things. So awesome to be able to see this National Monument! We only had a couple hours which was PLENTY of time. There's so much to do in that area! Next time we wanna stay a weekend or more.

I wouldn't make Mt. Rushmore my only reason for a vacation but we were about 30 miles away and ventured up...amazing landmark and history! I feel sad for the people complaining about $11 parking! It's well worth it just to say u have been there!

Fascinating sight to see. The entrance fee was $15 and it was good till the end of the year. There was a gift shop where they sell american made souvenirs and even jewelries. It's a must see place. Awesome! Two thumbs up!

For $11.00 it is worth every penny. This is the cost for parking admission is free. I walked the trail and they are groomed nicely and it is a great informative walk. Stay for the Eight PM closing ceremony it makes you feel proud to be an American.

Amazing and inspiring monument to four of our presidents. While there was no fee to enter the park, there was a parking fee which effectively rendered our Golden Passport for National Parks useless. The park was clean and service in the restaurants was good. You must stay for the lighting ceremony. The park ranger who gave the history and talk was excellent and included a tribute to our Veterans. I loved the patriotic swell of emotion as the crowd sang our National Anthem.
We refused to pay $11 each to park our motorcycles when we have an eagle pass. Instead we spent several hours at Crazy Horse which is much more impressive and has lots of things to do.

yes it is $11.00 to park there and theres no fee to enter. the monument itself is breath taking to see. there are numerous pictures and things about its construction. there is a gift shop and a few food stands. you really wont spend much time there.. take your pictures and take in the information and your basicly done. we hung out in the town of deadwood after wards
Don't miss this great American treasure! Make sure to give plenty of time and stay or return for the night show at 8:30 PM. Cost is $11 to park but free otherwise.
If you are in the area you should see this Monument. However, they do not accept National Park Passes and to park in a parking deck at a National Park is ridiculous.

We bought the annual national park pass this year bc we are traveling the states and plan on going to many of the national parks, but it doesn't work here. You still had to pay the $11 to park? Rip off!

It irked me that although the creator of the monument was very specific that no fees be charged, they got around that by building a massive parking complex and charge for 'Parking' instead of Admission.

The monument was rather smaller than expected, but the small museums did a fantastic job showing the history of how the monument was built. Several of the museum exhibits were interactive. Our nephew especially enjoyed the exhibit where you could "blow up" parts of the mountain. We also enjoyed the flag exhibit that showed every state's flag and when it became part of the United States. This is a must see since it's such a prominent American icon, but we probably wouldn't go back. Also, the $11.00 to park seemed a bit high.

I haven't been to Mt. Rushmore in over 15 years. It has changed alot, starting with new parking structure and shops. The nice thing is the parking fee is $11.00 however it does last for the rest of the year you buy it in.

Go around July Fourth. Someone told me to go for the evening show to see the lighting of the monument. Great advice! The ranger presented some history and invited all military past and present to come on stage. Then white lights illuminate the faces. It's very well done and not tacky which I feared. I went the following day to tour the studio and hear several presentations. Your parking pass allows multiple entries and is not covered by the national park annual pass so expect to pay $10. The best value is the coffee. ~$2.50 for an iced coffee with FREE refills. I drank two there and got one for the road (I got decaf but you can get full octane!)

This is one of those places you have to check off on your "see America" list. It's a neat site, but $11 to park and stare at carvings on a mountain just isn't amazing. I'm glad I went, but wouldn't make an extra trip to go again. And if there hadn't been other things to see and do in the area I would have been disappointed.

The memorial can be seen from the road so you dont have to pay. Just pull over and snap away. We chose to pay and only spent enough time to visit the gift shop, and snap a couple of pictures. $11 won't kill ya. Now we had the choice of returning and seeing this memorial at night or the Crazy Horse night blast. We returned to Mt Rushroom and wish we had picked Crazy Horse. The nightly lighting is a simple ceremony where lights shine on the faces. We could witnessed this from the road after visiting Crazy Horse. Oh well.

Best seen in the morning light. Just amazing to see the size and detail of the monument. Returning at night to see the night program was even better. Great presentation and seeing the monument at night is fantastic. The park charges $11 to enter but it is good until the end of the year so you only need to pay the fee once and then visit as much as you like.

My parents brought me here when I was a teenager and I remember that day vividly! What a joy it was to bring my own children here! And Wow, has it changed! Loved the trails all around the monument. You may want to bring along some water as it did get a little warm in Aug and with all the walking we were a little thirsty by the time we finished. We really enjoyed seeing a mountain goat. There are Rangers showing artifacts and my children could have spent all day around them gleaming their info. They loved it. So much to do here now! There is an $11 parking fee which was the best value of all the park fees we paid during the trip! The gift shop had every kind of souvenir imaginable, too.

Incredible to see. It was so worth the $11 parking fee. Went back in the evening for the lighting ceremony. We walked away feeling very proud to be Americans and grateful for the sacrifices others have made.

Visiting Mount Rushmore is affordable and easy to do. The only cost is parking ($11 for a family/group) unless you eat or go to the gift shop. The pass is good for the rest of the calendar year. It is well laid out and and easy to get around.

This was my 4th time, but first for the kids- they loved it. They got their ranger badges and all the park rangers were fun and helpful! We went back the next night for the lighting and ranger show which was great and honored the military, which as touching. The pass is only $11 and is good for 6 months.

We visited Mt Rushmore this July 4th and can't think of anywhere else I would rather have been. It is truly amazing to see, fun and affordable. Parking is only $11 per car, and your permit is good for the entire year! Breakfast was the first thing on the list as we arrived early, and the Monumental Breakfast did not disappoint! Reasonably priced at only $5.50, they load up your plate with eggs, breakfast potatoes, biscuits and gravy, and your choice of sausage or bacon. The staff were all friendly, one lady even stopped to talk with us for a good 10 minutes. The weather was perfect, sun block is definitely recommended if you plan to walk the Presidential Trail, which is a must. You get a much closer view of the monument, and some great excercise too. They have tour guides and presidential reenactors whom you can have your picture taken with as well. The only complaint is that for being such a patriotic facility, infringing on the Bill of Rights seems un-American..due to this we did not visit the museum or sculptor areas. Change that and I would give it 5/5. Either way it is a must see, whether you live in South Dakota or South Carolina, make the trip!

I visited Mount Rushmore Halloween weekend. I recommend visiting here anytime after Labor Day as crowds are gone and we pretty much had the town of Keystone & Mount Rushmore to ourselves. It is an awesome site, The Avenue of Flags leading up to the heads is great. You can stop along the road leading up to Mount Rushmore to take pictures, I doubt this would be possible in the "on season". Take the road leading to the other side of Mount Rushmore to get a picture of George's profile. For $10.00 you can also go back at night to see it lit up, we did it and it was pretty cool.

We came for the evening program. It was great. The tribute to soldiers in the audience was touching. Seeing the mountain lite up was spectacular. We ate at the restuarant there. You pay $10 for an annual pass. Well worth it.

This place is magical. We spend three days here as part of our month long road trip across the United States in 2014. We hiked all three bridges and man, what an experience! The first one is a mild hike down about 40 minutes depending on how fast you are. Don't rush! Take your time to soak in all the beauty. From the top you would never know what true natural beauty is until you venture to the bottom. If you wanted, you have the option to hike from the bottom of the canyon through all of the bridges and then back up at the third. The second bridge is the most hidden and beautiful. Especially in the fall months, the colors are unlike any I have ever seen. Just beautiful. This is a great place to visit for a long weekend to get away. The other great thing about this national monument park is how dark it is. Natural Bridges was coined the first International Dark Sky Park. I didn't quite understand what that meant until the fire was out and I couldn't see my hand in front of my face...literally. Looking towards the heavens we were speechless from the beauty above. I don't think any of us were expecting to see The Milky Way that close and visible. I would not only suggest but encourage everyone to see this amazing site as soon as possible. If you are an avid outdoorsman I would suggest the America The Beautiful Pass which gets you into more than 2,000 territories in the United States.

When it wasn't raining we were covered in dense fog. I think that made our hike through the lower trails off the promenade and up high near the overlook tower even better. The weather created an enchanted forest ambiance. Our only disappointment was finding that it cost $7 to go up the lookout tower-definitely not worth it in the fog (on a clear day maybe). Don't ever let the weather dictate your limits.
Absolutely a beautiful natural forest. Miles of nature to see and experience. Lots of hiking trails. Geat campground with full hookup for only $25 per day.

I'd never been there. Best to park around the back ( we took Wayne Ave to Maple Street to park) so we walked thru the little park for various views of the Falls! Then over the foot bridge. Later we went to the Paterson Museum and Libby's for food. There is a Lou Costello memorial we will see next trip. Great for NJ people looking for a tiny day activity! I wouldn't drive hours to visit (Niagara and Watkins Glen are worth driving miles to see)
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: Great falls itself is not as impressive as it is said. It is only second to Niagara in volume east of the Mississippi. But the fall itself is not particular high or wide. Drought may play a part, but not much. On the other hand, the history is rather interesting. Alexander Hamilton sought economic independence from England. He emphasized the importance of industrialization. To do so, one had to find energy sources. At that time, coal was the most important, but was not available in many places. Hamilton decided to harness the water power in the Passaic River. Paterson was created for the purpose.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: We've been to the Great Falls of the Passaic River several times. This time there'd been a bit of a dry spell in the mid-Atlantic so the water flow was not so impressive. We've been there when the falls was truly booming and it was quite a sight. So, you might want to pick your moment based on recent weather.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: Did the 90-minute Ranger-lead tour of this pueblo village that was on a major trade route. Barbara was our guide and was very informative. We learned so much history about the area and the way of life back then. It was so much more informative to do the tour rather than explore on our own. There is also a small museum which explains the history of the area. The ranger-led tour is free. However, there is park charge. If you are over 62, get the lifetime senior pass for $10 which gets you into any National Park in the US. The ranger at the desk was very informative too.

Stopped here after leaving Santa Fe and it was very easy to get too just off i25. Price is reasonable (free if you have a parks pass). The museum was good and the self guided walking tour was great. It gave a very good history of the pueblo and mission that were here.

Knew when we stopped that this Pueblo had been important through Indian, Spanish, and American history. What we didn't know or expect that Greer Garson (actress) had given money to build the very nice visitor's center which has hand carved beams and Adobe architecture. The well done displays are in timeline fashion with actual pottery exhibited that was dug on site. Definitely watch film and hike the trail through the ruins to truly appreciate the history and importance of this location. Greer Garson's Forked Lightning Ranch is part of park and Jane Fonda's Forked Lightning Ranch (private) borders the park on the south. We were not able to tour ranch as there are only tours on Sunday. However, we did obtain code for gate from staff at visitor's center and hiked/walked the Glorieta Pass Civil War site which is easy and well graveled. There are signs throughout the trail as well as a free hike brochure at trail beginning. The Civil War site was hard to visualize because of the growth,however!
I guess after looking at rocks and gorges for days, this was just ok in retrospect. I will also tell you to be careful to watch your speed...$130 ticket later, I can attest to this.
Wonderful views during the 28 miles drive from one end to the other, stopping frequently to take in the views. well worth the 20 dollar admission fee.

We spent 3 hours driving & stopping at sights of interest. Started in HQ, where employees were helpful. $20 at the entrance gate per car. Early stops featured colorful desert vistas. Later stops included ruins of village and petroglyphs, followed by increasing volumes of petrified wood. It was fun to get out into the terrain and explore the logs up close. Well marked, ez parking. Well worth the time.

The Petrified Forest National Park is fabulous. The Painted Desert is also picturesque. You drive around the National Park stopping at all the interesting sites. They give you a map and you follow all the signs. The Painted Desert is very colourful. Well worth a visit. You only pay $20 a car entrance fee but if you are visiting other National Parks its best to pay $80 for one year.

I always wanted to see this place. It did not disappoint. We drove through the entire park. The most interesting place, I think for tourists, is at the western end of the park. We enjoyed all the sights. It may have been smarter to go early in the day, when the pictures that we took would have come out better (lighting). If you are driving anywhere near here, don't miss it, like my dad did, when we were young. (LOL- better late than never). I got a National Park Pass, before our trip, so I'm not sure of the pricing.

Not the best petroglyph site that I have visited, but the park is split into several areas now with the encroaching business and residential development. The canyon we visited only cost a dollar and the hike was short.

If you like things like rock art, it's a must do. There are numerous trails that allow you to see lots of rock art. The kids liked it and we burned off some energy built up traveling in the car. There's a visitor center/gift shop with cool stuff. Go early if summer and carry some water. Did I mention the only cost was $1 for parking?

We tried to visit this - 1 hour later we gave up. We waited in the visitor center for 30 minutes while the ranger did Everything but help those with questions about the petroglyph trails. The brochures with maps cost $. We found the unsaved trails (not what we were looking for) but not the paved one with petroglyphs. We finally just gave up. Not worth it.

It's a little mountain trail that has rocks with drawings. No one knows what they mean or when they were done. There's self payment envelope for parking which suggests a fee to be paid. I enjoyed climbing he mountain but did not find those drawings interesting at all.

Stop at the visitor center first. Watch the 20min documentary then get your map from the main desk. The trail heads are not at the visitor center but at various spots around the city. Some are free while others charge $1-$2. It's amazing and scary how close these are to developments. Thankfully they stopped to save these pieces of history. Bring sunglasses, sunblock, and lots of water because you'll have to do some hiking to see most of these.

For $2 entry fee - you are able to hike the trails and enjoy the park. The trails are a bit steep / hazardous for me but my husband had no issue. Even if you stay near the bottom there are plenty of petroglyphs to see. Great park- recommend a stop there.

What can I say? Wide open spaces. Wind blowing away all my stresses. Feels like the plains up there. I love to sit quietly near the end of the day in the cave at the top of the highest volcano and just survey the landscape and the sky. The view overlooking the valley is impressive and really interesting. This is a no frills place to enjoy nature and so it's not too crowded and really peaceful. Please stay away so I can keep it all to myself. (haha) I would like to get married up there, under the moonlight. I don't think it's allowed.

We went to this national monument on our last day in New Mexico. We paid $1 to park and saw some amazing petroglyphs and sights, and hiked around. They had this impressive audio tour in which you call on your cell phone and press the number if the trail you are on. What a nice use of technology to keep a national monument affordable and informative!

With Tioga Pass still closed we had to change plans. Good choice to go to Pinnacles National Park! Awesome rock formations brought about the movement of the San Andreas Fault. Fantastic views all the way. Hats, sunblock and flashlight on brief moments going thru caves. Helpful rangers. Well marked trails. Guard rails, too! They are still developing their campgrounds tho. Drive via Hollister enroute to the East entrance to the Visitor Center and Bear Gulch trailhead. It cut our drivetime by 30 minutes-+ and used 680 all the way.
Very beautiful area. Looking Glass Falls is free, but there are a good many stairs to get down to it. You have to pay $2 per person to get into Sliding Rock. I love going to this area.

The campground manager was so rude when telling us we paid for one night in a double site, not two nights on a single as we had intended. Instead of showing us our mistake in a kind manner he told us it would be another $44 for that site or move to a single and pay $22. The sign was small and unnoticeable. Half of the sign that said double site was covered by a giant clip screwed on the pole to hold reserve notices.
Great place to spend time with kids and lot of history and culture here! Ancient carvings, huts, boats is all here for only $5 park admission. Free parking, can't ask for more.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Stopped by on way to Hawaii volcano national park. It was well worth the five dollar park fee. The sights and sounds was awesome. The presentation and figures were awesome
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We went snorkeling next door and then went through this Historical park. We paid the $5 to park and enjoyed 2 great things! It was a pretty neat self tour and each kid read off the brochure at the 16 walking tour spots.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Well worth the small fee ($5 when I visited). The historic grounds are beautiful to explore and wander at your own pace.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Be prepared to pay $10 to park. We were told this was a great place to see turtles. No turtles. Unfortunately, my husband wasn't feeling well and our two teenage girls were not interested, although I was. I think this could have been a great place to explore, but we only spent maybe 30 minutes here, not my choice. To be also fair - I over planned this day. Greenwell Coffee Farm, this, Green Sand Beach (did not do), black sand beach, Volcano, dinner, Lava Tube, and Crater/Jaggar Museum. It was too much.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We were surprised by how much we enjoyed the walk through Pu'uhonua O Honaunau. The location is picture perfect and the history is so interesting to learn about. You'll snap a lot of photos. Well worth the $5 entrance fee and you can also park here, tour the park, then go snorkel at two-step just a block down the road!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Unfortunately, we arrived here late in the day and just had about an hour. If by some chance you happen to be in the area by all means find this gem! $5.00 entry and it is amazing with beautiful trails, artifacts, pools of shallow water with fish, and a sign told of sea turtles. We saw none, but couldn't get enough of the tides hitting the rock-laden shoreline. There are native huts and totem poles. What a fun place to happen upon!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Super interesting & very beautiful. You can walk out onto the lava rock to see tide pools. Snorkeling nearby. Cool tikis. Clean bathrooms but no water/snacks sold. Arrive early because the parking lot is small & it gets crowded. Only $5 to park & free admission. Wear bug spray & sunscreen. Bring water. Probably need 1-2 hrs tops.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: If you enjoy learning the history of the place you're visiting, this is not to be missed. For $5 per car, you can do a walking tour of this ancient sacred spot and place of refuge. Be warned that it is very warm. Although you may only be there for a short time, use sunscreen and bring your water. Everything is well marked; you can even use your phone to get an audio walking tour.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Not too crowded, clean restrooms, and beautiful scenery. It's perfect for a quick pit-stop or spend a few hours meandering around looking at the tide pools and enjoying the view. The $5 entrance fee is worth the price for the restrooms alone.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We visited the park before snorkeling at Two Steps and we are glad we did! Quite interesting to learn the history about this village. Pay the $5 to park and tour the village, then walk over to Two Steps for some epic snorkeling!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We kind of stumbled upon this park on our first day here and we are glad we did. It's beautiful to look at- palm trees and ocean. There were tropical fish swimming in the little pools that the lava rock had naturally made. The waves were breaking over the rocks further out. The historical buildings were near to see and even my 4 year old was interested in them. There is a visitors centre with talks from the park rangers. We didn't see any turtles but the signs were there so maybe next time. Definitely worth the $5 admission!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Great visit. Recommend taking a dip in the ocean (swim, snorkel, etc) to get nice and wet/cool down before walking the grounds (very hot). Snorkeling is amazing, saw lots fish, spinner dolphins, eels, eagle rays, and more! Only 5$ for the week.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Husband and i headed there for a late morning trip. Arrived just as the 10:30am ranger talk started, which was phenomenal. Then we headed into the park. Bring your cell phone - there is a number to call for an audio tour, which was good. Wear sunscreen and a hat and sunglasses! There's not too much shade. There were two men in one of the huts making tools and weaving leaves. We wove little fish with the park ranger's father, who was totally adorable!!! We had a picnic lunch at 12:45pm by the neighboring swim area (no need to move your car btw). Then, using $7 snorkel masks we picked up at an ABC store we jumped in the water and snorkled until 3pm. Dont miss the snorkeling!!!! The water was calm, no need for flippers (children would benefit from the added control) - you float with little effort and it was easy to stay away from the shore coral/ rocks. Angel fish, puffer fish, parrot fish, the list goes on and on. Blue coral, green, etc - lovely! Headed back into the park afterwards to see if any green turtles had come to shore - two were there, sunning themselves not 10 feet away. We left and made it home well before sunset (4pm).
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We make it a point to visit National Historic Sites when we travel - we enjoyed stopping here and seeing the park! The tiki statues and mausoleum were very cool, and I appreciated learning about a sacred and historic place for native Hawaiians. Apparently turtles are often in the bay at the site, but we didn't see any the day we went. It's off the main road, but if you're interested in history/local culture, then I highly recommend this place! and if you have a National Parks Pass, it's free!

The trail starts at the Swiftcurrent Motor Inn at the Swiftcurrent Pass trailhead. The hike to Fishercap Lake is really short but offers pleasant views of the lake. It is 2.6 miles roundtrip to Redrock Falls. A little stretch for a senior, but manageably cool as we started early when parking spaces were easier to find. Worth the time and effort.
park: Red Rock Falls, Glacier National Park

text: It's a loooong drive out there but totally worth it. After braving the overly assertive California drivers and passive aggressive Northern California locals one should go to any and every national and state park with the Redwoods label. They are all located too far from major population centers to be weekend trip worthy so over crowding is not an issue. Feel free to stay in Eureka or Crescent City if need a place to regroup, though the locals are not the warm and inviting sort. A nice place to start would be Ladybird Johnson Grove just north of Orick.

My husband and I drove all the way the the Redwood National Park and state parks! This was a wonderful drive! We stopped at several of the trails and walked which was the BEST way to see the trees! I loved walking in the woods and seeing all the different aspects of the forest. There are lots of flat, short and easy walking trials! I really recommend making a few stops at trails and not just driving through. I do NOT recommend paying $6 at Meyers Flat to drive thru a a Redwood. Our Mazda 2 barely fit through the tree and the drive through was nothing special. We had already had amazing views of the trees on the walking trails that were a lot cooler! I loved the parks and the Redwood trees! I recommend you make the trip here and bring your camera!

We made a short stop at American Camp of the San Juan Islands National Historic Park, in our quest to fill our National Park passport books with as many stamps as possible. We didn't need our Annual Park Pass, because entry to this park is free.
park: San Juan Island National Historical Park

text: Took the Pass Trail to 12k. Wonderful views. Good trail. Not too difficult if you are in reasonably good shape and have acclimated to the altitude.

If you take state route 124 you will end up at Hesperius Pass. The drive is breath taking. You will need four wheel drive to get to the top of the pass. The round trip took 4 hours with time to eat and stop to take pictures

The address 401 Hillcrest listed above is offices. Don't go there. The Visitor's Center is at King Gillette Ranch is free and is located at 26876 Mulholland Hwy. The Visitor's center has excellent displays for all ages. Across the street on Las Virgenes Road. is Malibu Creek State Park. Excellent hiking trails. SMMNRA stretches along the ocean from Ventura County into Los Angeles. There are many hiking and biking trails, and beautiful beaches. All of this just a few miles from downtown Los Angeles. There are varying parking fees ranging from free to $12.00.
park: Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area

text: There is a table with the battle information that is very well done. The lights show the action of the battle in a very easy visual way to understand. The grounds are extensive. The importance of the Battle of Saratoga is explained through a video also. We were able to use our National Parks Pass here.

Located outside of Saratoga Springs. It's a little bit of a drive, through scenic countryside. Unfortunately the day we went, we did not realize how big this battlefield is and did not leave ourselves near enough time to see all we wanted. There is a roadway through the battlefield for a self tour in your car. We paid for the audio tour on the phone. (Small fee - 5 or 10 dollars) It was super easy. We just punched in the number and listened. I recommend that when you go. It adds so much to the visit. We got out of the car and read the informational plaques. Like I said, we only left ourselves a couple hours, so we rushed through. We are definitely going back next year to take our time. It's the kind of place you can go and learn each and every visit. The Visitors Center is staffed with friendly, knowledgeable people. You can tell they love their jobs. Hang around there first and listen to what they have to say. View the short movie - it enhances the experience.

If someone were to tell you that for $5 (a car) you could watch a video, talk to experts(park rangers), and tour what is arguably the most important battle in the history of the United States, you would probably think it was too good to be true, right? Believe it! This is one of the most effective uses of tax dollars I have seen, giving anyone who wants to take advantage of this gem a great day of learning and enjoyment. Don't miss the Schuyler house either, it's only a couple minutes away and well worth your time.

Fun and beautiful! Go to Morro Rock and climb those stairs. The view is gorgeous! Take the drive to Mineral King and take a hike up there, too -- way less touristy. Very remote and relaxing. It's $30 for 7 days of access -- not bad for all that you can see and do!
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Wish we would have done a little bit more research prior to entering Sequoia National Park. We arrived our first day from Visalia and it was backed up for at least a mile and a half and we finally got to the entrance at 1 p.m. the next day the backup was 30 minutes when we arrived at 10:30. I would assume backup is the worst from 10 through 2 on the weekends. Cost was $30 and you could use it for an entire week. The drive up was very windy and took longer than expected as 15 mile an hour speed limit and traveling up the mountain. Temperature at base was 95 degrees and at General Sherman 75. Wish we would have done the hike to Takopah Falls. Our drive to General Sherman from the entrance was approximately an hour and getting to the falls would have been at least another 30 to drive. Big elevation change from bottom to top. 7000 FT elevation change to get to General Sherman. The first Visitor Center, Foothills, had a nice recycled water dispenser if you have canisters or empty water bottles. Make sure your gas tank is full prior to entering!! Or at least you have enough to get back down and exit. We did not use a shuttle and parking was fine.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Passed through this park on our way from San Francisco to Las Vegas. I would have loved to stay here and hike for a few days, but unfortunately we did not have time to do so. Instead we drove from the Kings Canyon north entrance through the park, down to the area of the General Sherman. Here we walked around for a while. Such an impressive and powerful experience! Went out from the park at the exit further down south. Perfect weather - not too cold or too hot. Fresh air in October!
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: We spent the 1st night at Cold Springs Campground to acclimatize. We hiked up the 5.7 miles to Franklin Lakes 10,448 ft, it all differs. We were a group of 8. Experienced hikers can reach the lakes in less than 3 hours. The elevation gain makes it harder. First time mountain hikers took them 6 hours. Barely any shade, wear wide brim hat, water is abundant but you need to use a filter or iodine tablets for good measure. Beautiful rugged campground. Amazing sunset. Two of us woke up at 4:30 am to hike up to make the less than 2 miles, 1,400 ft elevation gain to Franklin Pass. We got lost a bit about 30 minutes searching for the trail in the dark. So better check the trail during daylight and mark it. Sunrise was amazing and the view of Kern Country was , too! 40 minutes descent back to camp. It was already light so we saw the trail. 5 stars.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Excellent choice. We're visiting the LA area but chose to drive up to take in the parks. Great decision. The drive through the Giant Forest, alone, makes this trip worth it. $30 for a one week pass - really good value. We chose to stay at a hotel in Three Rivers - short drive to the park and it made for a nice days visit. We arrived mid-day and went to the park then, after a good nights sleep, spent the next morning before heading back to LA.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: One of Americas greatest gems. Beautiful scenery. Absolutely breathtaking. Steep winding roads in some areas but the views are worth it. Sequoia trees are amazing. $30 entry fee per car. Would gladly pay that again. Allow more than one day if possible. If limited to a single day go early and do some research on best attractions within the park.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: This was definitely worth the $5 (per adult) entrance fee. Even the 17 YO that usually complains about museums enjoyed this one. We enjoyed the exhibits and then took a quick tour of the fort. There were several rangers at the fort that visited with us. They were even doing a short presentation on July 4 celebrations held during the L & C expedition, culminating with a musket firing demonstration. We spent about an hour here since we arrived so late in the afternoon. Even so, we felt it was worth the time. We got to see what we came to see.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: I visited the southern unit of Theodore Roosevelt National Park near the evening hours. I took the 36 mile Loop Drive, on which I saw prairie dog villages, several coyotes, wild horses, and buffalo. The Badlands are very Scenic and picturesque and you will certainly want to have your camera! There are trails for hiking and for horseback. I believe the cost for a private vehicle is $25. I have a senior lifetime pass, so that helped out with the cost. They give you a map, and information about the park, and the roads are very well-marked to guide you around the loop and any side trips you want to take.

Lots of animals in every season - great place to see buffalo, mule deer, horses, turkeys, coyotes, and prairie dogs as well as some beautiful views of the little Missouri river and the North Dakota Badlands - well worth the $20 entrance fee
Saw many wildlife animals. Including wild horses, badgers, prairie dogs, and buffalo. Cheap passes to spend days driving around. Make sure to have a full tank of gas.lol

Take your time exploring this area- The hiking trails are very well marked and kind to the less able. A map is supplied when you check in at the station; if you intend to be in the area for more than a day get the annual pass for $5 more and use it at the North Unit also. The park is well patrolled, family oriented, handicap accessible, and clean. Every one of the staff and volunteers we met were very gracious. The hikes are of good length. Be observant- you will encounter massive petrified wood specimens, vast prairie dog towns, large herds of buffalo, and beautiful vistas of the canyon. I will always recommend a hiking stick and ample water whatever the season. Prairie rattlesnakes can be found their habitat- look, listen, and stick to the trails. Watch and your footing but occasionally stop to scan the area you are headed into sometime lone bulls will be resting in peace; give them respectable distance to observe them.

This park is just off highway 94 in North Dakota. We went through the cute western town of Medora. Coming from the east it felt like you had arrived in the west. We enjoyed a walk around this town and had fun at the shooting gallery. We were charged only $10 for entrance into Theodore Roosevelt National Park.

We were directed here by a family member to see the wild horses and we are so glad we made the effort. We arrived early, around 6am and were treated to some beautiful vistas as the sun rose over the mountains. The shadows on red rock and the surrounding mountains were breathtaking. We hiked a fair bit around a few of the parking areas. Be sure to stop at Walgreens or Circle K to get your parking pass for the day. The $8 is much better than the $100 fine if caught without it. When we hiked from the Coon Bluff parking area to the East we were fortunate enough to see 3 of the wild horses drinking and grazing by the water. Was a great cap to the day. The only complaint we have is the amount of garbage and human made debris in the park. It was pervasive and distracted a bit from our enjoyment. Come on people you can do better than that, clean up after yourselves!!!

If you want a quiet place to sip your Starbucks, then a few minutes here might be worthwhile. Two cannons and a plaque do not make for a good historical site. Instead head to Baldwin Mississippi and visit Mississippi's Final Stands Interperative Site. It tells the story of the intertwined battles of Tupelo and Brice's Crossroads. The volunteers are very friendly, the museum is very nice and the $5.00 donation for the video is well worthwhile. Civil War author Shelby Foote narrates the exceptionalywell done 20 minute video.

Today I discovered that the history I was taught as a child about Valley Forge was incorrect. We took the trolley tour (3x a day, about $20) and discovered the truth about Valley Forge. What a fascinating story! Our guide is a history teacher and was so engaging & knowledgable that I highly recommend if you are in the area, go take the trolley tour, you will be glad you did.

Our daughters were getting "toured out" when we went to Valley Forge. Fortunately they had a 1 hour drive through tour. For $14.95 we purchased a cd with map and instructions of where to drive, stop and park.

Cost is $8 per person unless you have your national parks pass. It has two primary paths. The 1.6 mile loop has great history and interesting information. Beware that there are significant steps down and back up (240 each way). Rim trail is OK, about .7 mile in length.

We visited with two young children, ages nearly 3 and 5. We almost didn't go on the Island Trail because people were saying it was too strenuous but glad we did. It was quite ok. There were over 200 stairs, and then the paved path leveled out and went around the cliff dwellings. We took a lot of pictures as the scenery was amazing! You could sometimes hear the wind whistling between the rocks. Afterwards you climb the stairs back, but there were tons of benches where you could rest. It was 1 mile total, takes about an hour. If you don't stop much. Took us an hour and a half. We paid $8 per adult, kids were free, and the ticket was good for 6 days of unlimited visits.

There are so many neat dwellings here from the Hopi Indians. It's easy to see them because it's an easy hike and it's paved so you do not have to wear hiking boots. I enjoyed it. Cost $5 or you can use a national park pass.

Unplanned stop as we were heading east on 40 and wow it was great. Very interesting. $5 per person well worth it. We only has an hour there and wish we had at least 2 so we could have done the rim trail.
Nice location, quite place, close to White Sands in N M. Will suggest to try it. Price was ok.*********,**********
Was so surprised to see all the white sand. People were sliding down the hills with toboggans . Had bathrooms. Visitors center. Only $5 per person .

Yes the park is crazy awesome... it's like you are walking to the sea, but it never comes.... the sad thing is the coffee mugs were $30 at the gift shop and the typical $5 saucer sled and chunk of wax will cost you $20... we all tried to sled down the sand dunes: we all varied in body size, height and weight... it was a fail for all!!! We ended up rolling down the sand dunes and it was not worthy of the cost!!! Go see the park: don't bother with the outrageously priced gift shoppe!!!

The 5-mile hike is said to take 3 hours, we did it 2 and were glad we did. Got on the trail about 9:30 AM and was over 90 degrees by the time we ended. If you can get on by 8:30. Pay attention to water and have a salty snack. There will be no shade. Wonderful experience. If you can't do the long hike, make time to experience the dunes. A must see.

This site is a must when you r in the area. It is truest amazing- the biggest gypsum deposit in the world. Plus one can enjoy it more by sliding down the hills. Purchase ur plastic 'sled' at the gift shop ($15) or bring ur own. U can resell it back when finished. Go in the morning or late afternoon as it gets quite hot during mid day. Also they have wonderful covered picnic 'lean-tos' you can relax in. Don't forget to bring lots of water....

Did a road trip to White Sands National Monument with a friend and rented one sled at the visitor's center. Definitely worth the drive out from Albuquerque! The dunes are beautiful. Though we could've done without buying the $2 wax to make our sled go faster, it was a fun trip overall. This is definitely worth the drive out!

If you have teens do not miss this national monument! Our boys were in awe over the dunes and had a blast sledding and hiking around the park. We bought saucers at Walmart in Alamogordo for $5 each (much more expensive at the park store) and then gifted them to a large group of teens on the way out. Be sure to buy wax at the park store for $2 to make them more slick. You'll also need lots of water and sunscreen! There are restrooms and picnic tables scattered throughout the drive. Tip: for the largest dunes drive to the very back of the loop. The 15 min movie at the visitor center provided an excellent overview on how the dunes developed.

I loved White Sands National Monument simply for the fact that it is so special and rare. more than 250 square miles of perfectly white gypsum dune fields that feel like warm baby powder on your feet! Go there for a day trip! Make sure to buy a plastic saucer for dune sledding in advance to save yourself some money, because you will definitely want to go sledding down the dunes and the ones they sell at the Visitor Center are a little overpriced (17 $). You can go for hikes as well, there is a short boardwalk, a 2 mile loop and a 5 mile loop. I did all of them and they were absolutely beautiful but one of the loops is enough :) Bring at least a gallon of water, and lots of sunscreen the white sand reflects the sun perfectly and it manages to find its way everywhere :) Also bring sunglasses and a hat. Personally I was a big fan of playing frisbee on the dunes, its one of those rare times where you can actually jump safely with your entire body to catch the frisbee. If you are interested in wildlife, the earless bleached lizard likes to hide in shade of the bushes between the dunes, with a little patience and a good eye you will definitely find one. Also the Sunsets are breathtaking!

Spending the day at a place like this will add to those priceless moments we all need to have with our families. Bring something to sled with or buy the discs for $15 at the gift shop. A major highlight is that they are dog friendly. It's easy to drive through. The sand is packed hard like concrete. Views are breathtaking

Amazing and beautiful!!!❤ You can buy plastic sled or try cardboard to slide down dunes. It is so much fun!! The sand is soft and cool (supposedly in summer as well). I recommend taking shoes off and feel it between your toes! It is so quiet and peaceful. They have pucnic tables with wind guards and places to rinse off or use restrooms. Don't pass up the chance to go! Only $5pp. If i lived close by I'd go all the time!

The White Sands was AMAZING! Majestic, beautiful and awesome photo ops. Sledding is very fun but not mandatory for a great time. Good luck buying your own sled at a reasonable price. We searched Walmart, Target and Dicks Sporting Goods with no luck! So we reluctantly purchased one sled and wax at the gift shop. It cost $20.18, a little pricey for a plastic saucer and a cube of wax. You'll have a beautiful connective feeling to the earth here it is so serene. I would defiantly come back and enjoy more time at White Sands and Las Cruses La Garage AirBnB!

An amazing place. Watch the video at visitors center first. Pack a picnic lunch. Definitely take a sled. You can also purchase a new one at gift shop for $14.99 or a used one for $10. They will purchase them back too. The sand dunes are awesome and the sand as fine as talcum powder. Do not miss this place if you are in or going through Alamagordo. It's a wonderland. The day we went the computers were down so no entrance fee. Plus we have a National Park card.

Good fun for a group of you. They sell sleds with a refund at the gift shop on the way in, but we'd got ours at the Alamogordo Walmart for $6 beforehand. Gypsum sand is weird - like packed snow in some ways, and stays cool even in the hot afternoon sun. Easy to drive around the dunes in a car and pick your slope for fun sledding!

But if you go in summer, later in the day and especially full moon nights. They often have free concerts then. Plus the dunes are magical under a full moon. Charge up your cameras as the photo ops are wonderful in this beautiful park. Take water and be sure to notice the position of mountains and mesas if you hike as the dunes move. Tourists have gotten lost here. Which is really hard to do if you just use common sense to take water and noticed what direction you are traveling.

The park has always been fun. I came here when I was young and now taking my young children continues to be fun. Fun place to spend early morning or late evening to avoid the heat in the summer but it is great in year around specially in early spring and fall. Be ready for a workout climbing up the sand dunes and take plenty of water and sun screen. The entrance is only $5 per adult so very affordable. Dont forget to stop at the Alamogordo Walmart to get your sled and a candle to rub wax on the bottom of the sled. If you are coming form another direction or do not want to go to Walmart, you can buy sleds there for a little more and sell them back when you leave. Fun for the whole family and for all ages.

I've wanted to visit for sometime now, though I'll admit, part of my coastal self was thinking, how much time can you actually spend enjoying white sand with no ocean? Well, let me tell you, we could've stayed ALL day! The sand is gypsum and is cool to the touch all year long, and if you dig, it's even cooler beneath the surface. We have kids 12,10,8, and 6, and they all enjoyed digging, burying themselves, playing in it as it's wet and moldable beneath the surface, running through it, and rolling and sliding down the dunes. We bought discs at the local Wal-Mart for $6 each. We only needed two for our family of six and were fine. The adults had just as much fun as the kids. We would definitely go again!

This was by far one of the coolest places I have travelled to. Upon arriving, you are able to purchase a sled from their gift shop. I bought a used one for $8. If you are traveling with more than one person, definitely purchase a sled for each individual - it will be much more fun that way (trust me!). My boyfriend drove and parked inside the monument. There was plenty of space to go and it was not crowded at all. Once we parked, we took to the sand hills! We went "sand sledding" which is just as fun as it sounds. In addition, the place was great for pictures as well. Be sure to note where you are and where you're walking because it's very easy to get turned around in the dunes.
Passing through, again, on the way to Tucson.

Seriously, though, this place is a must-see if you're ever in the neighborhood, especially if you're a photography buff. Surreal landscape and yet another reason to contemplate the wonders of nature. And they only charged $5 for five days. Such a deal!

your $5 entry fee is good for 7 days to one of the most unique places you would see. A 16 miles loop drive takes you through the dunes, but it is when you walk barefoot on the cold white sand that you get where you are. All you see are white dunes surrounded by mountains, people sliding on the dunes, a few Ravens looking for food. If it is windy you could see a stunning white out, or on a clam day see awesome white sands against blue sky with white clouds. Stay around for the sunset stroll ranger-guided one hour walk, a great photo opp. Hike the backcountry trail where you find the best untouched sands for your photos.-best in the morning- Sands reflect the warmth of the early and late sunlight great for photos, and during the day overexposed by 2/3 to get white not gray sand. The picnic areas are your only shelter form the sun. use them. All in all a beautiful place to photograph. Very friendly and knowledgeable staff at the visitor center.

Had a great experience with my family, husband and two daughters 9 and 12. Only $3 per adult which was great too! There are sleds to rent/buy at the gift shop but we didn't realize that until we got out on the dunes. Luckily, however, we had two different people offer us their sleds once they were done as long as we would turn them in for them, saving us some money. Nice bathrooms throughout park! The only con was that the girl working in the gift shop was very rude and not helpful. Some people who didn't speak English very well were talking to her and she was not very helpful to them at all.

I had been trying to get down here for around 8 months, but things kept on interfering with my plans. Finally, I drove down from Albuquerque, and kept a beady little eye on the weather forecast. The last thing I wanted was for it to be windy as my plans were to backpack in with my two dogs and do some astrophotography at night. Driving in, the winds picked up, putting a lie to the weather prognosticators. Damn! So, I decided to go ahead and got my back country permit which is $3 + $3 for the entry fee=$6. A bargain, though they plan to go up to $5 this year. Still very affordable.

What a marvel! Heaps and mounds of gypsum dunes. Turn the corner and you are on the moon! The landscape is unworldly, austere and one feels immediately alone. I sat on a dune and wrote in my diary. The weather is perfect in March. Price is right and this natural wonder should no be passed up. I didn't! A photographer's dream location.

I enjoyed the view, the hiking the dunes, walking the boardwalk and reading the tidbits of information posted. The Visitor Center was informative and the staff very friendly. You read or hear about sledding down the sand dunes. It's nothing like sledding down a snow hill. I found it difficult and more work than fun. ***Buy or bring your own plastic saucer sled*** Do not fall for the wax in the gift shop. It doesn't work. One sled is $15. They will give you $5 back with your receipt and resell it for $10. I didn't like that. I was astounded at the $28 coffee mug. I did not enjoy the ridiculous prices. Take water. I'm not kidding. Take water! Overall, it's beautiful like a infinite beach... Clean, amazing sunsets and plenty of dunes to climb and slide down or roll down! Just be ready for insane prices! It's worth the entry fee, which is reasonable.

I guess there is no need to talk about the beauty of this place. Snow-looking sand, How great is that! There is an enterance fee of $3 per person but there are a few days in the year that this is fee is waived. You can check the White Sands website to see those dates. The gift shop in the visitor center is great. There are many hand-made stuff there and anyone can find something there to buy. They also rent sleds if you are interested. I visited this place in August which was very hot, but absolutely worth the visit. Oh, Just don't forget your sunscreen and your cameras/phones! Also, you are going to walk on sand. So, wear something like flip-flop (You don't want to bring sand in your car!)

This national monument is such a steal - it only costs $3 a person! Considering the price of other parks / monuments and other attractions in the area this one is very inexpensive. I'd suggest watching the short video before starting into the monument - it plays every 30 minutes or so. There are two gift shops, mailbox, snack bar and a water fountain - make sure to have plenty of water before you head out because there isn't any available once you leave the welcome area.

OK, you want a perfect visit? Here is the Deal. After breakfast, head out from your hotel and hit the visitor's center, buy your disk for sledding, watch the movie, shop and do the Junior Ranger activities. NOW, drive out...plan to spend less than 30 minutes and DON'T SLED now. Get out, perhaps scale a dune, look at all the people that are there sledding! They are getting a sun burn ;) YOU are going to get out, find out the sand is not hot, and it is like powder, you are going to ooooo and aaaaawe. Drink some more water. Get back in the car, go back to the hotel, let the kids swim, take a nap and then about an hour and a half Before sun down head back out to the sand! THIS is when the fun starts. Once the sun heads downward the temp drops fast to a very comfortable mid 80's...The sledding is excellent and you don't drop dead. As the sun sets great family photos are so possible...and the Frisbee is excellent, toss the Frisbee to those sliding down the dune! It's great. The park closes at 9 and a park ranger will come by on loud speaker to make sure you don't overstay! This is the best approach in my opinion. You get to see how spectacular the sands are during the day, but evening is the best, the critters come out and you don't roast. We left our disk at the visitor center as a gift to the first lucky family there the next morning :) The disks are under $15 and we only got one...if you have more that two kids you might want two. Take water, there is none available in the park.

If you're ever in the area I highly recommend stopping by this park. It is unreal how far these perfectly white dunes stretch. I had sunglasses on and it was still hard to see with all that white around! You should definitely rent a sled ($10 for a used sled with $3 buyback) and slide down the dunes - so fun! I was there on a particularly windy day, so be careful because it can wipe away your tracks in minutes. The wind was also quite nice because it kept the area a lot cooler, and I can imagine it being unbearably hot in the sun. Definitely wear sunscreen, even if the sun isn't shining.
This is our second trip to White Sands. The sleds are 16.99 each and you get a five dollar refund if you bring it back. They do have used sleds for ten but they are rarely available.
This place is amazing! Whole family enjoyed it. Make sure you buy a sledding disk at the gift shop. Used ones are $10 & they will buy it back for $3. Also it's a good idea to take water & sunscreen!

My family of five thoroughly enjoyed visiting White Sands. We went early in the morning (10 a.m.). We bought sleds at the visitor's center for $10 each. Very much worth it. Our three kids ran, rolled, climbed, sled, laughed, and squealed to their hearts' content. Going early in the day meant less crowds for us. Highly recommend you see this place. It was worth the drive.

Beautiful place. Nice to visit for the novelty; a day trip for a picnic. If you've climbed one large dune you've climbed them all. Pay attention to where you're at so you don't get lost in the dunes and don't forget your sunglasses, sunscreen and water.
