We didn't know what to expect so we took the Garden of Eden tour. Well worth the $10!!! Sheena was an awesome Ranger guide. She shares a lot of her Lakota heritage and really brought to life how sacred these caves are. I enjoyed learning about the history of the caves. I'm amazed at how big this cave formation is. Don't miss s tour if you have the time. This one was very easy and lasted about an hour.
We decided to try Wind Cave National Park before paying the $10 per person charge at Custer State Park. There were hundred of Bufflo. Some came right next to our car!

We started our tour in Hot Springs and headed North though the park viewing the wild Buffalo herds, Prairie dogs and other mid Western wildlife. Stopped to take the guided 1 1/2 mile Cave tour. It was interesting, excellent and so much different than the Eastern caves that we have explored. The formations are vastly different and the cave has an interesting history among the American Indian. Well worth the $10 admission cost. The tours can get crowded and parking space can be hard to find so we suggest getting there before 11 AM.

We did the Natural Entrance tour. $12 per person. Less strenuous than some cave tours. Mostly downhill, ending with an elevator ride back to surface. The box work formations are fascinating and different from almost anything we've seen in other caves.

We did the Fairgrounds tour and Ranger Lauren was our tour guide. She did an awesome job! Around 40 people on the tour, so a little crowded, but was not too bad. The tour goes down to 220ft and it is 1 1/2 hour tour. Lots of walking, lots of stairs and lots of places you have to bend down as to not to hit your head. Stop in maybe five rooms for talks from the Ranger. Caves are special for their cave formation called the boxwork (looks like honeycomb). Ranger Lauren did a great job of explaining the cave, she had very animated stories and she even through in some humor. Pack a hoodie - it is around 55 degrees in the cave. We were there over the 100th national parks anniversary celebration weekend, so we're able to get in free. It is only like $12.00 to get in though, so super cheap activity to do with the whole family. Great job National Parks!

Most people would rate this as one of the outstanding global attractions and I would concur with this view. I have written separate reviews of some of the key attractions in the park, but I'm using this review to give a general overview. Firstly, as many have said, you need at least 3 days in the park to do it justice. The $50 week pass, including entry to Grand Teton, is exceptional value, as there are no additional charges once inside. Staying inside the park will cut down driving times, but the costs for this are very high, so you need to balance cost against convenience. Canyon would be a good option as it is very central. We stayed at Grant, which was convenient for the Geysers, but at least a 4 hour round trip to the Lamarr Valley.

We were heading to Horseshoe Bend when we discovered we had to drive through Zion. It cost us $30 to go through, and because we had no other options that we could see, we paid. Oh man, it was probably the best $30 I spent that weekend. Zion park is incredible! I have never seen such natural beauty in all my life. It was unreal. If you can, you should definitely go see it before you die. My only regret is that we didn’t stay longer and go for a hike on one of the hiking trails. Next time perhaps, and I guarantee you there will be a next time.

I hated to rate this park average but to do the amount of people I had to. We were here middle of October and it was like you were in the city visiting. We got to the park early and the sign said no parking in park. FULL! So our options were to catch a bus from Springdale into the park or you can pay an additional $20 to park in a lot near the park. Keep in mind it’s in addition to the park fee itself. Then once in you have to take a bus most everywhere as they don’t allow cars on the scenic route. For us that just stinks as we like to drive at our own pace. The bus wasn’t bad though. There are many stops and they pick up & drop off every 8 minuets I think. We chose to do the river trail which was nice and the little hike up to the narrows which is 2 miles RT. This was crazy too. There is just way to many people to even enjoy the park. IMO do yourself a favor and go to Bryce instead. Zion is way overrated buts it’s beautiful. If you want to see it’s beauty and fight with people all day go to Zion. We visited 6 NP on our two week trip out west and this was my least favorite:-(

Ah, Zion! we never have enough time when we visit you! There are sooooo many things to do in this park, but not enough time. This is always the last leg of our trip (this was our second time), that's why we don't get to spend as much time, here as we want to. Parking is always full. You can pay $20 for parking outside of the park, close to the visitor center and take the shuttle from there. We'll definitely be back.

I wish I had read the reviews before I visited this park. I only had one day and had to choose between Zion and Bryce Canyon. I definitely wish I had chosen Bryce Canyon. The only part of the park that is accessible without fighting huge crowds to ride the shuttle is the drive through the canyon. The parking lot to the Canyon trailhead was only accessible from the other side of the road, and you could not make a left turn at that point because of the tunnel.. All of the other points of interest in Zion are along the route that is only accessible by shuttle, would you have to drive into town and pay to park to utilize. Needless to say, this was not mentioned when they take your $30 at the gate.

Even from the approach this park is spectacular and what you pay for an annual pad ($80 at the time of this review) is such a small donation compared to the work and commitment that fits into making America's national park's sustainable and intact for future generations.

We love Zion Canyon. The drive in is fantastic and the view is great. Park your car and take the free bus around the scenic way. You can get off at any stop and walk around. Very well organised. Make sure you buy an annual pass for $80 it is cheaper than paying at each National park.

Zion is a must-do if you are anywhere near Las Vegas or Salt Lake City. It's tucked almost half-way between the two cities, and yet seems to be a world away when looking at its landscape. The drive to the park is spectacular and at one point, the road suddenly turns red, and you feel like you're on another planet. The best thing about this park is the shuttle system. Park your car and hop on the shuttle. From there you could just stay on and see its natural beauty, but you can stop at any point and take in a trail, the visitor's center, the museum, ice cream or lodge. We chose to go to the last stop and take the river trail to the Narrows. We spent some of our time traversing the Narrows and after some debate, we were glad that we all wore tennis shoes and all rented a walking stick. You can obtain sticks and even boots before getting on the shuttle near the parking lot. They're $7 and well worth it. The stick saved me from sinking many times while on this trail. Although the trail is beautiful and the cold water is refreshing, it was a lot of work for someone who's not entirely in good shape and unless you plan to go all the way to Wall Street (where it actually gets narrow), you many want to consider not doing this trail and just sticking to the river trail. We took a lunch to eat while on it and just enjoyed our surroundings. After, we went back to our car and some changed shoes and socks; I kept mine on and I was dry in no time. We then did the Emerald Pools; we were only going to go the the lower pools, but someone along the way encouraged us to go all the way to the upper one. Again, for someone not in great shape, this is not easy considering you are going up with some steep cliffs, rocks, and others behind or in front of you and you have to make your way back down...but we went ahead and went to the top. It was nothing special to be honest. The lower pools at least had a small waterfall. My brother-in-law and niece conquered Angel's Landing in the time we changed shoes and did the pools. They're rock stars. All-in-all, if you don't have a lot of time to do any trails, just drive through as far as you can and take the shuttle up and back down. The scenery out of your window is breath-taking.

Very well kept national park. We have the senior pass; absolutely the best deal ever @$10.00 and good for your lifetime. Covers yourself and up to two others in your vehicle. Good at any national park in the country. Many trails to hike. Plenty of pull offs to park so you can snap those photos. Best photography early morning and later afternoon. We saw big horn sheep and a family of mountain goats including a youngster.

I stayed in Charles Town to enjoy my trip to Antietam and loved every minute of the visit. The battlefield is sprawling and well kept with countless impressive monuments. One day is not nearly enough to enjoy this priceless piece of history. Try Captain Benders Tavern in Sharpsburg for a great lunch and two dollar beer. An absolute must for any Civil War buff! Can't wait to visit again!!
It cost $11 to get in. It is a must see. We didn't buy any food it was too expensive for us. You can see it from the road but it's worth stopping in.
